item.title: La boeuf
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It's all been very stew-based of late. It makes sense. The veg box is full of root vegetables---and it's pretty cold outside---but I had a hankering for something lighter, and spicier than our usual casserole staple; and after the Yuletide excesses I was avoiding anything roasted. Or turkey-based. I've had my fill. We had a glut of root ginger, and a terrifying chilli pepper was nestling amongst the celeriac and carrots begging to be utilised; we'd also received a generous serving of Bok Choy in the veg box. Plus, the cupboard sauces demanded a raid---left to fester, I feared the fish sauce could be morphing (nay fermenting) into something else. (Does fish sauce ever go off? I may have to ask Google, since Jeeves has now sadly departed. ) [caption id="attachment_1112" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Bringing out the bottles"][/caption] Inspiration was simple: the boy was drinking sake; I stole a couple of glugs; added some brown sugar; lime juice;  a generous heap of grated ginger; and soy sauce and left thin strips of beef marinating for about 45 minutes. [caption id="attachment_1111" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Marinate a while"][/caption] I only wanted to lightly cook the steak, leaving the pieces almost rare in the centre and I was hoping to retain a buttery tender texture without having to coat the beef in flour. [caption id="attachment_1107" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly cooked"][/caption] While the beef cooked in the ginger-soy marinade; I prepped the veg and mixed chilli sauce with soy, lime juice, some palm sugar, rice vinegar and a teaspoon of ground ginger for extra zing. [caption id="attachment_1108" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A wok full of veg"][/caption] The vegetables were easy; some fresh ginger, leeks, cabbage, purple sprouting broccoli, carrots and some rogue sweet peppers. The latter being less seasonal, but nicely colourful. Sod it. [caption id="attachment_1109" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="High heat"][/caption] As the vegetables only took moments to cook, the beef was still warm. I plated the veg and sat the beef neatly on top, drizzling the excess sauce over the meat for extra flavour. Chopsticks added, we eagerly tucked in.

item.title: Not quite an Anzac
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I'm clearly a faux Digital Native, as I'm only setting up a blog now in August, 2010. And, truth to be told, even that wasn't my idea. It's all thanks to illustrator Johanna Basford---creator of the lovely Edinburgh Fringe covers in collaboration with Whitespace---who suggested I abandon the endless twitpic-ing and start food blogging. So here we are... I love to cook, to share ideas, to eat food with, and learn from, others. So, when the boy said the blog was a good idea, it all seemed to fall into place. Once resolved, I realised that for a pseudo-perfectionist, like me, it would take too long to choose the right thing to publish as a first post, so slow-baked Anzac cookies (for the weekly office bake club) seems a simple place to start. About three months ago, the Whitespace girls set up a bake club. Monday mornings have been spiced up with a home-baked sweet good---it's the best way to start the week. Truly. Cooking for other people is one of my favourite ways to spend time. We launched the club with chocolate and ginger biscotti (just thinking about them makes me want to make those again: add stem ginger and some dark chocolate shavings to a standard vanilla biscotti recipe) and now, a few months later, it's my turn to bring in the next batch of sweet stuff. It's worth noting that, currently, the oven doesn't heat above 100 degrees Celsius, and I'm without scales, hence the half-Anzac, half-something-else status of these baked goods. [caption id="attachment_21" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Slow-cooked, with a chocolate twist "][/caption] Everyone knows the Anzac; the recipe is simple. I've chucked in some nuts for good almond-measure. 1/2 cup melted butter 1 tbsp golden syrup 1 tsp bicarbonate of soda 2 tbsp boiling water 1 cup plain flour 1 cup caster sugar, or soft brown sugar 1 cup desicated coconut 1 cup rolled oats 1/4 cup plain chocolate chips 1/4 cup toasted flaked almonds Heat your oven, ideally to 180C. Melt the butter and syrup together. Dissolve the bicarbonate of soda in the boiling water, then stir into the syrup and butter mixture. Mix the oats, coconut, flour and sugar in large bowl. Create a well in the middle, and pour in the syrup and butter mixture. Slowly stir to incorporate all the dry ingredients. Place spoonfuls--try desert-sized--onto a buttered biscuit tray, flatten slightly, and try to leave about an inch between each to leave room for the mixture to spread while cooking. Bake in batches until they're golden. With a working oven this probably takes around 10 minutes; I left mine in for 20. They haven't turned out quite the way I intended, but the good news is the oven is in the mail... [caption id="attachment_30" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Enough to feed the Whitespacers "][/caption]

item.title: Courgette and pumpernickel
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: To celebrate the arrival of a new oven, some sort of oven-based event was required; but summer evenings---for me, at least---demand salads, assembled from a medley of whatever vegetables are lurking in the veg-box, or on offer in the local shop. [caption id="attachment_47" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="From the cupboards: peas, peppers and a lone courgette"][/caption] At home we had some courgettes and peppers, as well as my current staple (and summer addiction), peas, so salad was the easy option. A few leaves with a lemon and mustard dressing, was easily assembled. [caption id="attachment_48" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Easy summer salad"][/caption] But, the oven was there. (Is still there, I should note.) And, I couldn't help myself. So, pumpernickel roundels were layered with griddled courgettes, camembert goats cheese, and slices of chorizo (one remaining slice of parma harm, made it in there too). Very random, but satiating none-the-less. Courgettes and pumpernickel, it seems, go hand in hand when you have an oven. [caption id="attachment_49" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Delighted to be oven-cooked"][/caption]

item.title: Bonjour Belarus
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: So, the boy is packing his bags for his big Eastern Europe adventure; Edinburgh to Chernobyl, via Minsk, Berlin and Belarus. (Actually, there's a lot more on the itinerary, but that's for his blog, not mine.) I've read the Belarus travel advice---low threat, apparently---and aside from the visa requirements (simple) and strong warnings against photographing government buildings (less good) the only thing I can garner is that the boy won't be eating peas, peppers and pecorino. Or whatever other summer thing I've been dishing out of late. Tonight's supper, therefore, is a bunch of things we both enjoy. Although we eat a lot of chorizo chucked on goats cheese, working around the corner from a great fishmongers (Welch on Queensferry Street) facilitated a quick lunchtime trip for fillets---sea bream. Often, I like to bake fish simply, with some lemon juice, a mix of thyme and parsley, pepper, butter, salt and white wine. It takes no time to throw together, and even less to cook. [caption id="attachment_68" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Sea bream parcel"][/caption] Wrapping the fillets in individual parcels, the bream was cooked---yes, in the new oven---at 180C for around five minutes. The boy put together the remnants of the fridge: an orange sweet pepper; plum tomatoes; fresh peas; a little gem, and some watercress. Fish cooked; salad dressed---ready to eat! [caption id="attachment_70" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Sea bream on summery salad"][/caption] Pre-Belarus supper wouldn't be complete without pudding; at least, I'm an addict for sugar and it tends to be a quotidien feature. Tonight I cheated. Courtesy of Urban Angel the boy and I ate my favourite: cheesecake from a box. (Berries added purely for their non-Belarusian quality.) [caption id="attachment_69" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Best cheesecake in Edinburgh"][/caption] And now it's time for some Woody Allen, and last minute packing.

item.title: Brunch for my sister
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: A departure was swiftly negated by an arrival: that of my sister. And, for me a guest means brunch. [caption id="attachment_99" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Eggs, chives and asparagus "][/caption] The sister had suggested poaching the eggs, but I need no excuse to scramble. Inevitably, this won't be the last time I post about scrambled eggs---everyone, has their own view on how to make "the best" scrambled eggs---mine are still very much a work in progress. (You can't fail by reading Mark Bittman's summary of two approaches; both are delicious.) Once your method is established, how long you actually cook the eggs for is controversial; who knew eggs were such divisive nourishment? I've known friends to send their plates back to the kitchen (not mine, yet) for being overdone, or too gloopy and runny. Basically, we all like our eggs they way we like them. Fair enough. I've adopted the slow-pan approach; slowly cooking the beaten eggs on the lowest heat, for the longest time. Sister was asleep, so this was easy. [caption id="attachment_119" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Slow cook: eggs in a large pan"][/caption] I picked up some fresh chives; some Phantassie eggs, and some coffee. [caption id="attachment_100" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Scrambled, with salmon and asparagus"][/caption] Bad cooks blame their equipment, and I'm apt to curse the cooker when I neglect to remove the pan from the heat swiftly enough. 40 seconds too long; I was distracted by some talk of the Con-Lib coalition on Radio4. (Gah.) Oh well, the eggs were pretty good; the sister was pleased; but more practise---and a bigger pan!---is definitely required. It's Sunday tomorrow... [caption id="attachment_101" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Sister sits down to brunch"][/caption]

item.title: The ABC of Gourmet Cookery
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I've just finished reading Nora Ehpron's Crazy Salad. I loved it. Pithy and amusing, I found some of her arguments (both feminist and political) were still pertinent, despite the decades that have past since she first wrote those pieces. What resonated with me most, however, was her description of how she reads food magazines. Maybe, that's too general; it was her description of how she reads Gourmet (the now defunct American food magazine) which made me smile. Perhaps it's how many of us read food magazines. I don't buy food magazines anymore, because after the initial food-and-inspiration euphoria I become plagued by guilt if I don't cook what's contained within the bound pages,  and regret ensues when the printed sheets are consigned to my recycling bin. Again. Guilt aside, why buy a a magazine when you can plunder the excellent NYT dinning section for ideas, or rummage through charity shop book sections for old editions of cookbooks? Waitrose is full of recipes to trial, and Jamie Oliver's site is packed full of recipes desperate to inspire aspiring cooks. (The ingredient sourcing can occasionally be a struggle.) I digress. I was reminded of my love of old books this weekend when I spotted a copy of The ABC of Gourmet Cookery in Shelter. It will sit proudly on my kitchen shelf. (Temporarily, nudging Thomas Keller's Bouchon out of primary position.) [caption id="attachment_132" align="alignnone" width="392" caption="Charity find: The ABC of Gourmet Cookery "][/caption] From it readers can attempt Russian Borscht, as well June Peas, à la Française, Dream Crescent Cookies and Jubilee Cherries. Perhaps, I'll read it in bed. If I'm not cooking, then I'm thinking about what might be nice to eat later. Bed is as good time as any to have an idea about supper. But lest we forget, according to the editor's note: this Peter Pauper Press book is for "first-class cooks" who need "a little courage to explore new culinary horizons". And the recipes are "reputation-making for the cooks that use them". Quite a promise! There's nothing else to add, except I intend to report back... [caption id="attachment_131" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Source of inspiration, or bedtime reading "][/caption]

item.title: Making granola
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded:
Making granola is one of my favourite tasks. More accurately, it used to be a task but now I look at it as a lovely morning ritual. Or a late evening one, when the oven is cooling and I'm expertly avoiding the washing up. There's something very relaxing about the routine of toasting jumbo oats, roasting almonds with maple syrup, and mixing honey with whatever random seeds are lurking in the cupboard. The basic technique is always the same; sometimes I change the extras. [caption id="attachment_196" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Oats, ready for the oven "][/caption] On a decadent day, I melt butter. (I love melting butter. I'm a fully paid-up member of the butter fanclub---what's not to love?) Although 'healthier recipes' use olive oil---and it's a good alternative--- a couple of tablespoons of melted butter really help the oats gain a golden colour. Occasionally, I replace half the honey amount with some agave nectar---a concession to health, you might say. Whatever works, really; there are no hard and fast rules with granola. Either way, it always starts with a lot of jumbo oats, some cinnamon, maple syrup, almonds---and when I remember, pecans and brazils, but any nut you like will do---some raisins, and honey. There are lots of brilliant granola recipes out there (the BBC Good Food variant is a great place to start), and I'm sure you have your own, but below is the combination of oats to nutty goodness that I enjoy most. Granola recipe
  • 6 cups jumbo oats
  • 3 cups whole almonds (or 2 cups almonds and 1 cup pecans)
  • 1 cup organic (essentially, untreated) raisins
  • 1 cup sunflower seeds
  • 1/2 cup sesame seeds
  • 1/2 cup poppy seeds
  • 1/2 cup linseed
  • 1/2 cup desiccated coconut (I don't always add this, it's a personal preference)
  • 2 tsp ground cinnamon (some ground ginger adds a good zing)
  • 2 tbsp maple syrup
  • 3 tbsp honey (or agave nectar)
  • 2 tbsp melted butter, or olive oil if you prefer
Heat the oven to 100C/fan. Mix all the ingredients, except for the raisins, in a large bowl. Make sure all the oats are coated with the butter, honey and syrup. Tip your mixture onto two large baking sheets---I sometimes used large roasting tins---and spread evenly. Bake for 10 minutes, remove from the oven and stir to ensure an even coating. Bake for a further 15 minutes and then add the raisins. [caption id="attachment_245" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Nearly golden "][/caption] Return to the oven, bake for a another 15 minutes, or until the oats look golden. Remove from the oven and leave to cool. Once it's cooled, store in an airtight container. [caption id="attachment_198" align="alignnone" width="589" caption="Granola mix: just out of the oven "][/caption] (Note: if you opt for walnuts they burn faster, so I'd add them after the first 10 minutes of cooking, rather than at the beginning.) The boy and I like to eat granola on top of lashings of yoghurt. Recently, I've developed an addiction---call it a food-related dependency---to stem ginger soaked in syrup, so I add a bit of that (finely chopped) and a handful of whatever fruit is around. Right now, I'm chucking berries on top---there's the summer soft fruit glut, so no need to be frugal; but in autumn, when all sorts of apples are available they're my ideal topping. The above recipe should last for about a month, but no matter how much I make it lasts no longer than a fortnight. (It's a good late night snack, as well as breakfast; in fact it works as an afternoon energy boost too). Anyway, have a whirl, and feel free to let me know how it goes. [caption id="attachment_197" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Ready for eating"][/caption]

item.title: Inspired by French yoghurt cake
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Having spent a weekend ill, retching akin to a poor parody of "Vomiting Veronica" (and consequentially missing a close friend's wedding owing to my head-over-the-loo status) choosing to bake---and write about it---may seem a strange recovery response. But then, thinking about the food I might successfully consume once my appetite (and accompanying digestive system) returned somehow spurred my recovery on. At least, leafing through my recipe cuttings collection while lying woe-is-me-style in bed, coupled with blog-browsing on the boy's iPad, kept me occupied while I was positioned horizontal. It also meant I could view myself as more productive, than pathetic; the latter, of course, being the truer state. [caption id="attachment_265" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Lemon zest: citrus zing"][/caption] I don't own the "right pan"---who does?---I gather when reading Emily Weinstein's lovely blog about learning to bake. None-the-less the lemons in the fruit bowl, and the ease with which she describes assembling the ingredients, has inspired me to bake a version of Dorie Greenspan's French yoghurt cake. I feel hungry just looking at the pictures, partly because I've not eaten anything more substantial than apples and some celery for the last 48 hours. [caption id="attachment_266" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sweet and sour: rubbing zest with sugar"][/caption] I'm cheating, slightly, because I haven't ventured out, so canola oil is replacing olive oil---which will add a more distinct flavour---and the "pan" issue means I'm trying the circular option, in place of the loaf tin. The olive oil should lend a richness to cake, which I hoping will be tempered by the sharpness of the lemon zest. [caption id="attachment_267" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Adding yoghurt and eggs"][/caption] Oh, and cream in the fridge means I can attempt some sort of shortcake filling; which seems apt for the last official weekend of summer. Sponge and berries with whipped cream. [caption id="attachment_268" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly whisking"][/caption] Other than adding some soft brown sugar as well as ordinary caster, putting in a little more lemon zest, and using olive oil in place of canola, I've pretty much followed Dorie's delicious recipe. Adapted from Baking From My Home to Yours by Dorie Greenspan (Houghton-Mifflin, 2006). Ingredients 1 cup plain flour 1/2 cup ground almonds 2 teaspoons baking powder Pinch of salt 1 cup sugar Grated zest of 1 and 1/2 lemons 1/2 cup plain yogurt 3 large eggs 1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 1/2 cup flavourless oil (I used olive, which isn't flavourless, but still works well) Method Preheat the oven to 170C degrees. Generously grease an 9-x-2-inch round cake pan, and place on a lined baking sheet. Whisk together the flour, ground almonds, baking powder and salt, and set aside. Put the sugar and zest in a medium-sized bowl and, working with your fingertips, rub the zest into the sugar until the sugar is moist and aromatic. (This part may be messy, but the intense aroma makes up for it.) Add the yogurt, eggs and vanilla to the bowl and whisk vigorously until the mixture is very well blended. Still whisking, stir in the dry ingredients. Use a large rubber spatula to fold in the oil. By now you’ll have a thick, smooth batter with a slight sheen. Scrape the batter into the pan (loaf tin, or circular cake tin) and smooth the top with a palette knife. Slide the baking sheet into the oven and bake for 35 to 40 minutes (10 ir so minutes longer if you've opted for a loaf tin), or until it will be golden brown. Use a knife (or skewer) to test: insert into the centre of the cake and it should come out clean. Transfer the pan to a rack, cool for 5 minutes, then run a blunt knife between the cake and the sides of the pan. Cool to room temperature right-side up. Using a serrated knife, cut horizontally into 2 rounds. [caption id="attachment_269" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Before "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_270" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="After"][/caption] Admittedly, my wasted weekend had left me with a hankering for cream, coupled with a desire to see out the summer with a berry-topped cake, but it would be just as delicious, and certainly much lighter, to make a simple lemon syrup to pour over the cake. This is easily done while the cake is in the oven. Lemon syrup Juice and zest of 1 lemon 50g caster sugar Put the lemon juice and zest, sugar and 100 ml water in a small saucepan and bring to the boil over a low heat. Increase the heat and boil until the amount has reduced by half and ressembles a syrup. When you take the cake out the oven, immediately pour the syrup over the top and leave to cool for longer in the cake tin. Then place the cake on a wire rack to cool completely. However, if you're in more of a cream-and-strawberry-type-of-place, as I was, opt for a filling similar to below. The filling A punnet of strawberries, hulled, halved of quartered depending on size (keep a couple whole to scatter on top) 284ml pot double cream 25g caster sugar 1/4 tsp vanilla extract Lightly whip the cream with the sugar and vanilla extract to form soft peaks. Put the base piece of cake on a plate, spread with a generous layer of cream and cover with spoonfuls of berries. Cover with the top cake piece, the remaining cream and berries. Sit down, and eat, immediately. Briefly back from the abortive-Belarus adventure, the boy had a guest; the lemony whipped cream ensemble didn't last long. [caption id="attachment_262" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Adding berries and whipped cream "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_264" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="You can never have enough whipped cream "][/caption]

item.title: Salmon, wrapped up
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Autumn has arrived. And, with it a desire to try new things. While the boy is tearing down layer upon layer of wallpaper, I'm in the mood to make parcels. Throwing a heap of food together, wrapping it in baking paper, and awaiting the results is---perhaps, in a childish, or undeniably girly way---exciting. I enjoy the anticipation of the meal, as I'm never entirely sure what will emerge... [caption id="attachment_300" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="DIY: the beginnings "][/caption] I'd had a hankering for salmon---and the boy is in the thrall of Asian cuisine---so some kind of soy-and-ginger infused salmon parcel appealed. We scouted for Wild Atlantic fillets; and the rest was an easy assemblage of leftover vegetables (leek, sweet pepper, broccoli,and carrots) with some fennel added for its delicious aniseed flavour, ginger for warming spice, and some chestnut mushrooms for a more authentic Asian touch. [caption id="attachment_301" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Prepping the vegetables "][/caption] I sauteed the sliced leek with some fennel, and tossed the rest of the vegetables in a mixture of sesame oil, honey, soya sauce, and Linghams chilli sauce. (I've not got around to making chilli jam yet---Linghams is a perfect bought concoction; they also do a variant with ginger. Great too.) [caption id="attachment_302" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ginger and chestnut mushrooms "][/caption] I wasn't sure how this would turn out, but followed basic parcel principles: brush the paper with some oil; layer up with sauteed vegetables; then add the fish; season, and top with the dressed vegetables. [caption id="attachment_303" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ginger-dressed salmon on sauteed vegetables"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_304" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Topping: chilli-and-soy covered vegetables "][/caption] That's all there is to it. Creating the parcel was more fiddly than I remembered. A good cook uses a little egg white to help the edges seal. I was (too) hungry to separate yolk from white, so just folded the paper inwards, tucked one edge under and placed the packaged fillets on a ceramic tray. I cooked the fish parcels for ten minutes (this really depends on the size of your fillet), at 190C. Unwrapped the packages, plated, added some chopped coriander and ate, immediately. [caption id="attachment_313" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Unwrapping"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_314" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just add some chopped coriander "][/caption] The jury---the boy---has returned its verdict: I will be making this again... (And, for anyone who'd like it, writing the recipe too.)

item.title: Meringues for Sarah
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Whipping egg whites into a frenzy isn't going to make up for missing Sarah's wedding. She was however, cooking dinner for the boy and I and I'm always loathe to arrive anywhere without bringing (making) something, so I had the perfect excuse to trial meringues in the new oven. Sarah can't eat diary---meringues are the perfect answer. [caption id="attachment_331" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Separating the whites"][/caption] I'm afraid of meringues. It's irrational, I know. I've told myself it's because meringue-making is overhyped. All the chatter about temperature, over-beating, texture, and type of mixing bowl has contributed to my fear. It's been a good few years since I've made a pavlova, and even then I was following my mother's foolproof recipe, and during all that time the meringue angst has grown, reducing me to something akin to inertia. (I'm aware I sound as though I've developed a egg-white-whipping syndrome of sorts...) Convinced that I couldn't arrive for supper without miniature cocoa-flavoured white marshmallow-textured sweet things I bit the bullet. [caption id="attachment_326" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Slowly beat"][/caption] Clearly bemused, the boy watched while I searched all my cookbooks for a trustworthy recipe. My bookshelves didn't satisfy. We looked online; too many choices. And, then I remembered a recipe by Orangette that  had struck me as reassuringly straightforward. [caption id="attachment_327" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Add sugar, beat faster "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_328" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Simply fold in chocolate"][/caption] Some items were missing from my cupboards---I didn't have cocoa nibs, which no doubt are better than plain chocolate chips. And I used a quarter cup of icing sugar, as well as granulated. But what follows is essentially Orangette's recipe. [caption id="attachment_330" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Oven-ready: egg white dollops"][/caption] 45 minutes later, much to my delight, I opened the oven to find rows of perfectly formed meringues; still white, not cracked. I can't recommend this simple approach enough. They melt on your tongue, still soft---not too chewy---on the inside, while retaining their crumbly outer skin. [caption id="attachment_332" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Leave to cool"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_336" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A first attempt: crisp and white"][/caption] We packaged them up; added a bottle of something fizzy, and trundled off to Sarah's to fill them with berries and cream.  At Sarah's, where we gorged ourselves on smoked ham with roasted vegetables, I whipped cream, and we assembled our meringue and raspberry sandwiches over glasses of champagne. (They're still happily ensconced  in wedding mode.) I can't wait to make more---thank you Orangette. Meringues with chocolate, adapted from Orangette's recipe. Recipe 1 tsp pure vanilla extract 3/4 cup granulated sugar 1/4 icing sugar 1/2 cup egg whites (4 large eggs), preferably at room temperature Pinch of salt 1/2 cup of plain chocolate chips To serve: Whipped (unsweetened) double cream Raspberries (or any other fresh berries) Makes: about 20 small meringues Place two oven racks in the upper and lower thirds of the oven, and preheat to 100C. Line two baking sheets with baking paper. In a large ceramic bowl, whisk the eggs whites and salt using a hand-held electric beater. Start on a low setting, and slowly increase the speed to the medium setting. Beat until the mixture holds soft peaks and the egg white bubbles are small, about 2 to 3 minutes. Increase the speed to medium-high, and slowly add the sugar, bit by bit. Continue to beat the mixture until shinning, stiff peaks form. The bowl will suddenly seem cloud-filled. This takes about 4 minutes. Add the vanilla at the last moment. Gently fold in the chocolate chip. (If you've found cocoa nibs, true to Orangette's recipe, use these.) Immediately spoon the meringue mixture onto the lined baking sheets. If like me you're currently without any type of piping device, using a tablespoon is the easiest fallback option. Scoop up a dollop of the mixture onto the spoon and gently place on the tray, in whatever form you like. (Mine were pretty abstract peaks.) You should be able to fit around 10, spaced, on each sheet. Place the sheets in the oven. Bake for about 40 to 45 minutes, rotating and switching the sheets halfway through. If, when you open the oven they appear to be cracking or browning, reduce the temperature slightly. When the meringues are ready, remove them from the oven, place them on a wire rack and leave to cool. Whip some cream, and enjoy. Keep any unexpected broken pieces for a decadent breakfast topping...(or a spontaneous Eton mess). In an airtight container they should last for two weeks.

item.title: What's for breakfast?
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: We eat a lot of breakfast. As a nation, and more particularly---and closer to home---the boy and I. I'm useless without it. And, I spend a considerable amount, probably too much, time thinking about it. Scrambled eggs are a favourite; easy, and always comforting. If there's bacon, I like to add a splash of maple syrup. But only on Sundays---chalk it up as another strange human habit, or simply a peculiarity of mine. The change in season, however, called for something more unusual. The boy and I had really enjoyed making Moroccan eggs with tomatoes and cumin, from Casa Moro, The Second Cookbook, the smell of cumin had warmed the flat, and the eggs were rich and creamy, a perfect pairing with the sweetness of the tomatoes. The fridge dictated that we still had peppers to eat, and I'd seen a recipe for eggs with peppers and cumin in Ottolenghi's new(ish) cookbook, Plenty,  which tickled my morning fancy: it was exotically named, Shakshuka. [caption id="attachment_362" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Shakshuka: the Edinburgh version "][/caption] Of course, the pictures are stunning in Plenty, and a fair few of the recipes rely on a bountiful store cupboard; my pantry---if I had one---is not, yet, stocked with the full gamut of Eastern spices, so what follows is very much inspired by, and adapted from, Ottolenghi's recipe. I omitted, and substituted; and the pictures are far messier, but I'm officially adding this to weekend breakfast fare. It was delicious, and there's plenty of room for variation; I'm already salivating at the prospect of some spicy chorizo, or possibly a sprinkling of a salty cheese, although I realise this deviates from true Shakshuka. [caption id="attachment_363" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Shallot and toasted cumin"][/caption] Back to the eggs, and the shallots... [caption id="attachment_368" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Add sweet peppers and chopped herbs"][/caption] This is a recipe worth prepping for. I toasted the cumin seeds in an oil-free pan, and set to work finely slicing shallots and peppers. While enjoying the aroma emanating from the shallot-filled pan, I minced the herbs and de-seeded a red chilli, taking care to avoid touching my face. You'd think I'd know to avoid the chilli-hands and face collision, but I apt to walk straight into that, every time. [caption id="attachment_369" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Plum tomatoes in the mix"][/caption] After adding the peppers to the pan, with the sugar and the herbs, the mixture of sweet and spiced aromas left me dreaming of adventures in North Africa---I'm easily distracted. After 10 minutes of day-dreaming, and mentally planning that trip, I added the tinned tomatoes, the chopped chilli, salt and pepper, and a splash of water. Next, came the tricky, and the less photographically apeitising bit: the eggs. Ottolenghi does recommend separate pans for each portion. Saving on washing up, and being in breakfast (read sleepy, reverie-filled) mode, I stuck with what I had. [caption id="attachment_370" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Crack the eggs"][/caption] I made gaps, and I broke the eggs---I admit it's not pretty---and then I popped the lid on top. And waited. The recipe recommended 10-12 minutes on a gentle heat; it's worth taking the pan into consideration too; I only cooked ours for 9 minutes. They were perfectly poached. [caption id="attachment_372" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="They ain't pretty, but they sure taste fine "][/caption] After that, it's simply a case of getting the eggs out of the pan, and onto a plate! The boy was hungry so I added toast, and a salad for him. Mine were happily, straight from the pan, with a sprinkle of coriander---it tasted really, really, good. In all honesty, although I didn't make it "correctly" the whole thing was still piquant. It's nutritious, easy, and could definitely feed a fair few for weekend brunch. Try it. (Use saffron and cayenne pepper as additional extras.) Recipe (adapted from Ottolenghi's Plenty) Serves 2 very generously 1/2 tsp cumin seeds some olive oil 1 large shallot 1 red and 1 yellow papper, cut into thin strips 2 tsp muscovado sugar 1 bay leaf 1 tbsp finely chopped parsley 1 tbsp finely chopped coriander, and some of a garnish 1 tin of Italian plum tomatoes (if you have fresh, 4 ripe tomatoes) roughly chopped 1/2 deseeded fresh chilli 4 medium eggs salt and pepper to season In a large pan---skillet---toast the cumin seeds on a high heat for a couple of minutes. Add the oil and the sliced shallot and sauté for about 5 minutes. Next add the peppers, the sugar, the minced herbs and the bay leaf, and continue to cook on a high heat for a further 10 minutes. Reduce the heat and add the (tinned) tomatoes, chilli and salt and pepper. Cook for around 15 minutes until the mixture ressembles a pasta sauce in consistency. (You could make this in advance.) Remove the bay leaf, make small wells in the mixture and carefully break an egg into each gap. Season the eggs and cover the pan with a lid. Cook for 8-10 minutes, or until the eggs are set. Remove from the heat; use a wooden spoon and using a flat turner without slots, if you have one, and plate. Serve with some extra coriander on top, and some bread (if you fancy) to mop up the sauce.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Breakfast perfection, in both smell and taste; definitely a fine way to start the day.
Oh, and you WILL want to mop up the sauce.

item.title: Autumn roast chicken
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Last night, we ate a lot of butter. I love butter, but even I postprandially baulked at the amount we managed to consume. A bellyful. Keen to acknowledge Autumn's arrival, the boy had requested roast chicken for supper---naturally, I acquiesced. Always game to butter a bird and roast some vegetables, I couldn't pass up the opportunity to tackle the purple cauliflower, which had arrived two days previously courtesy of Phantassie's veg box; I've never encountered a purple cauliflower in my kitchen before. [caption id="attachment_390" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="The arrival of purple cauliflower "][/caption] Everyone has their own chicken approach; emulating Julia Child's famed poulet rôti was tempting, as was re-creating Thomas Kellner's simple roast chicken---for one reason, or another, I rebelled and dared to attempt the feat sans guidance. [caption id="attachment_391" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Preparing the bird "][/caption] In fully-fledged hunter gather mode---yes, occasionally we Millennials embrace the type---the boy sought out the chicken. I wasn't confident enough to heed Nigel Slater's advice to roast our bird naked. Instead our ample, corn-fed chicken was stuffed with a lemon, several sprigs of lemon thyme and an onion. I rubbed butter all over, and under, the skin, then covered it in salt and pepper, and added some garlic to the roasting pan. [caption id="attachment_392" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Getting ready to roast"][/caption] The cauliflower required more consideration. Most recipes online tend to talk of its health-giving properties (anti-ageing, and cancer-preventing---a high achieving brassica by all accounts) rather than its flavour, so in the end we opted for roasting. I added some whole garlic cloves, oil, and lemon juice and seasoning. (I'd read that it also goes well with chilli.) [caption id="attachment_394" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Drizzled with oil"][/caption] For some reason we were forgoing potatoes. Blasphemous, I know. We settled for some leeks, braised in butter with (end of season) garden peas, and some roasted carrots with red onion and thyme. [caption id="attachment_395" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Carrots, onion and thyme"][/caption] A word on basting: it's worth doing. I basted the chicken three times during its hour or so (I hour 15 minutes at 190C) in the oven. The first time I brushed the bird with butter---yes, more butter---and spooned the juices from the chicken over the skin. A mere fifteen minutes later there was more than enough dripping in the pan for a second basting. (And, then a third.) [caption id="attachment_396" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Second basting "][/caption] The kitchen was filled with a rich, buttery aroma. I made myself a drink, the boy laid the table and we waited for the chicken to cook. By this point I was feeling anxious. Ridiculous, I know, but it felt as though a lot was riding on this Sunday-supper chicken; the roasted bird I'd (potentially foolishly) free styled with. [caption id="attachment_397" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Our first roast chicken "][/caption] Serendipitously, upon opening the oven, the bird's golden colour did not disappoint. And yet, the cauliflower stole the show. It's vibrant lilac hue was transformed to a deeper purple, and without the addition of cheese to mask its unique texture and taste, it remained nutty in flavour and crunchy to bite. We piled our plates and ate well. [caption id="attachment_398" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="An autumnal plateful"][/caption] Next time, I'm following a recipe to learn how the real chefs do it.

item.title: Tomatoes and a marrow
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: The marrow arrived in our kitchen, unannounced, in this week's veg delivery. Bland and watery, this oversized courgette-cum-cucumber presented a culinary dilemma: what on earth can you (should you?) do with a marrow? [caption id="attachment_438" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Kitchen Gladioli"][/caption] Marrow recipes tend to talk about stuffing: stuffed with sausage; or tomato; or some rice and parsley concoction; or---and, I consider this a definite low point---a quorn mince and onion stuffing; I have little affection for stuffing. Still, I was prepared to believe the marrow was an unnecessarily much-maligned vegetable, just waiting for its chance to be back in vogue. Simon Hopkin's recipe for Marrow and tomato masala in his divine The Vegetarian Option saved me from the mince and stuff variety. He elevates the marrow to a vegetable of interest. [caption id="attachment_439" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Deseeding"][/caption] As usual, the best laid plans often go awry. While I'd intended to be boiling chicken bones and making masala for the marrow, a friend arrived with her newborn in tow. Naturally, I was happily distracted by gurgles and a cute button nose. The boy was therefore left in charge of our  quasi-cucumber. [caption id="attachment_440" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Tomatoes and marrow"][/caption] After leaving the sliced, deseeded marrow to wallow in a vat of salt and leak some excess water, the boy made masala. (Note: he didn't photograph his paste making, so we'll have to repeat the procedure for posterity. The jar in the fridge may last us a month.) [caption id="attachment_441" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Slowly cook"][/caption] Once inside the oven the onions and masala mixture infused the kitchen with such an exciting smell. And the marrow left me pondering its metamorphosis. [caption id="attachment_444" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Baked, and ready to eat"][/caption] The result was surprising. My only contribution was to throw some chickpeas into bowls at the end. (I needed something to counter the marrow; I'm not quite a committed convert.) But the recipe is really wonderful. And, if a marrow appears in the kitchen again, this is what we'll be making. Recipe (by Simon Hopkinson) Serves 4 1 marrow 2 onions, peeled and thinly sliced 2 garlic cloves, peeled and sliced 2 tbsp vegetable oil 1 tbsp masala paste 12 curry leaves, fresh or dried 750g ripe red cherry or baby plum tomatoes freshly ground pepper 50g butter, thinly sliced Method Preheat the oven to 160C/gas mark 3. Trim the ends of the marrow, cut it in half down through the middle and then halve each piece lengthways. Scrape out the fibre and seeds with a teaspoon and then cut each quarter in half yet again, also lengthways, giving 8 marrow "boats". Sprinkle salt generously over all cut surfaces and place the marrow in a colander for about 40 minutes to leach out a modicum of the juices. Rinse and dry in a tea towel. Meanwhile, in a large lidded pot, fry the onions and garlic in the oil until golden. Add the masala paste and stir around for a few minutes. Lay the marrow pieces, skin-side down, on top and add the curry leaves, if using, then tip over the tomatoes. Season and dot with the slices of butter. Cover and place in the oven to cook for about 1½ hours. Delicately decant into deep soup plates, so each one has 2 pieces of marrow, a spoonful of the tomatoes and plenty of aromatic broth. Postscript : This evening I added some chopped root ginger, a punnetful more tomatoes, a third of a can of creamed coconut and raw prawns. Somehow, marrow mush became prawn masala curry, and it was delicious. Definitely making this one again, if only for the leftover potential.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
While it did turn into a tasty meal, I can't help but think we could have cut out the middle-man and just had a masala chickpea salad.
Oh yes.
Look forward to utilising the spread on more exciting substrates.

item.title: Caramel for Angela
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded:
Today was Angela's last day as a Whitespacer. And us ladies, fledgling bakers that we are, decided to throw her an impromptu tea party. It was actually more of a lunch-time affair, but all things tea party related was never-the-less the theme. Therein, however, lay the conundrum---what do you bake for the Queen of Tarts, the woman behind Edinburgh's pop-up tea room, and its dainty delights? She can tell you the difference between a conserve and a preserve, make Danishes for breakfast, or beetroot chocolate cupcakes for elevenses, with no fuss or fluster, and always has a new recipe on the go. Knowing there would be an array of lemon drizzle cake, some savoury snackettes and delicious tray bakes, I opted to trial a smaller bite. An attempt at chocolate-coated caramel was my answer. Midway through caramel creation, I questioned my solution. I had skipped the corn syrup, and had no thermometer. And that, I have learnt, was the fundamental flaw... [caption id="attachment_488" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Chocolate dipped fudge "][/caption] As a caramel and fudge neophyte, I had not appreciated the complexity of burning sugar. The temperature has to be perfect for the texture to be right. Apparently. Over-ambitiously, and foolishly, I was inspired by a recipe from Kitchen Culinaire: chocolate-dipped seat salt caramels, what's not to love about that idea? I skipped the cardinal rule: be sure of your ingredients and your equipment. [caption id="attachment_477" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A large dollop of Jersey cream "][/caption]

Is there anything more decadent, and consequently satisfying, than cooking with Jersey cream? It's the sort of cream your spoon will remaining standing in because of its wicked thickness. Adding butter and sugar is a mere trifle after that.

Gleefully, I tipped all the ingredients---minus the liquid glucose---into a pan.

[caption id="attachment_476" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Melting the sugar and the fats "][/caption] At this point, I became aware of  the temperature issue. (A tad late, yes.) I now know that all fudge (or caramel) recipes talk about reaching the optimal temperature; around 110C. Apparently, perfect fudge depends on the formation of sugar crystals at the right time, and the correct temperature. Yesterday evening I was blissfully unaware of this important detail. For those who want more of the science detail, the Joy of Baking offers a little. [caption id="attachment_478" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ten minutes later "][/caption] Ever the optimist, I watched as the sugar, butter and cream began to melt and hoped for the best. [caption id="attachment_479" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bubbling caramel "][/caption] The transformation from creamy-butter gloop to bubbling caramel is quite exciting. Stirring furiously, I deferred to the boy. Could he please check the caramel consistency? The colour? The texture? But he is a boiling sugar novice too---it smelt right, apparently. [caption id="attachment_486" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to cool"][/caption] So we hazarded a guess as to the general look and feel of the sugar mixture, and poured the hot, golden liquid onto a baking tray, and waited for it to cool. [caption id="attachment_487" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="In the morning "][/caption] Things didn't look so good at 7am. The cooled mixture had been refrigerated overnight. So far so good. But, the result was a large crumbly, buttery, fudge-like slab, that disintegrated the moment my knife attacked it. Cutting the slab into 1 inch wide strips, and then 1 inch squares was not an option. Disheartened, but determined I melted some chocolate---it can hide all manner of sins. And so, with espresso in hand, the boy and I took turns in dipping fudge splinters into the melted chocolate, tapping, and placing the pieces on the tray. [caption id="attachment_489" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Fudge: dipped and ready to eat"][/caption] In the end, it was fine. Angela had a great tea party, and much fudge and other goods (include Nigella's cocktail sausages and marvellous chocolate-topped marshmallows) were consumed. Next time, however, I'm using corn syrup and a thermometer, and hopefully I'll get to properly trial the chocolate-dipped sea salt caramel recipe that first inspired me so.

item.title: Purple kohlrabi
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: My mother loves kohlrabi. I remember it featuring, albeit briefly, in our evening salads during my teenage years---I've not encountered it much since, and I'm not entirely sure why. Perhaps, we Brits have a propensity to be confused (or unamused) by its irregular (nonconformist) shape and unusual flavour. Certainly Nigel Slater, beloved of all, has no time for the sputnik-shaped root. I remain loyal. Purple, crunchy, and perfect coupled with sliced apple and walnuts, this gargantuan vegetable arrived in our kitchen late on Thursday evening; I was, unsurprisingly, delighted. [caption id="attachment_519" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Purple vegetable in our kitchen"][/caption] The boy had never encountered the swollen bulbous brassica until I forced it upon him while we were galavanting around Berlin; serendipitously, on our second day in my favourite European city, a stall at the Kollwitzplatz market was purveying mini kohlrabi. Eager to try, the boy and I snacked on cherries (enthusiastically donated by some housing marketeer) and chunks of kohlrabi, washed down by Ratlinger, in bright Berlin sunlight in the park across the street. [caption id="attachment_520" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Too pretty too slice "][/caption] The kohlrabi remained a table decoration---how kitsch, I know---until last night. Tired, and hungry, I hankered after some sausages with something simple. Feeling too lazy to caramelise onions and slowly cook tomatoes---a supper staple down our way---sausages and salad seemed rather appealing. I sliced two coxes, julienned some kohlrabi, toasted some walnuts, squeezed a lemon to make a light mustard vinagrette, and whacked the sausages under the grill. The result? Simple sausages atop a crisp and crunchy salad. I'll be happy to eat this all week long. In fact, the remaining kohlrabi---it's far too big for two---may be the ideal addition to the recurring beetroot and carrot coleslaw that has become a recent favourite. Either way, I love you kohlrabi; sorry Nigel. [caption id="attachment_518" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Venison sausages atop a kohlrabi-themed salad"][/caption] For now, the only question is what to do with the tiny pumpkin, or gem squash. Do I have the appetite---or energy?---to make sage and pumpkin ravioli? Simon Hopkinson's squash, sage and pine nut ravioli sounds worth perserving with.

item.title: Leftover vegetables
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: So, here we are. The kohlrabi I recently---and naively---wrote an ode to has defeated me. A week later, and it's still here. It's been put to good use: eagerly snacked on; easily absorbed by beetroot and carrot coleslaw; and offered the leading role in a salad; yet, still it remains. Large. And ever present in the kitchen. [caption id="attachment_574" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Cabbage calls for use"][/caption] And that's not all. No. There's a cabbage. A beautiful leafy, savoy cabbage that laments its neglect. (As I write this I'm naturally wondering why the vegetables have taken on such vivid characters; let's call it a one-off, for now.) There's little worse for a stalwart veg-box fan than feeling defeated by the weekly contents before Winter has even begun. I'm overdramatising, I'm sure. There's nothing a stir-fry can't fix, instantly. [caption id="attachment_575" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Vegetables: easily transformed "][/caption] Fortuitously, there was some chicken in the fridge, so I turned to a reliable staple: honey and ginger chicken. The secret to this sticky, caramelised chicken is the marinade: honey, diced fresh root ginger, soya sauce, sesame oil, a tablespoon or two of lemon juice and some pepper. [caption id="attachment_573" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Marinade a while"][/caption] For me, the sticky, carmelised ginger chicken pieces are the perfect antidote to the ostensibly holier-than-thou cabbage and broccoli---cleansing and nutritious as they are, the less than healthy chicken swiftly dilutes any smugness I might feel about the cabbage consumption. And, once marinaded (for 30 minutes or so) the whole thing easily comes together. [caption id="attachment_576" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Pan fry and add seeds"][/caption] On a medium heat, cook the drained chicken pieces for about 3 minutes, until they are opaque. Add sesame seeds and the marinade sauce. Cook, stirring occasionally to ensure an even coating, for a further 5 minutes. At this point chicken will begin to caramelise in places. [caption id="attachment_577" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Waiting to caramelise"][/caption] After adding the sesame seeds, this is the point at which I tend to furiously heat the wok, add groundnut, or sesame, oil and start frying onions and ginger; next I ready myself to chuck in broccoli, cabbage, peppers and whatever else is lying around. If I have fresh chillies, I add some of those. I like to retain the crunch and bite of the vegetables, so I never stir fry the vegetables for more than a few minutes. [caption id="attachment_578" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sticky and sweet: ginger chicken "][/caption] When the chicken has browned, it's a juggling act of pans, and plates and sauces and serving, and a minute later it's done. Supper is sorted. [caption id="attachment_579" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just add vegetables "][/caption] We didn't have any coriander or spring onions, but both are the ideal garnish. I wolfed my down, and the boy had leftovers for lunch.

item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Sometimes, only steak will do. With caramelised onions and homemade chips, lashings of bernaise sauce, and a glass of red wine---just as my father used to make---steak deserves decadent accompaniment. [caption id="attachment_618" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Simply done"][/caption] It's been a tumultuous week, and chargrilled steak slowly became a dietary fantasy which required immediate realisation. Naturally, given the laws of nature---or simply Sod---my desire for a steak blowout was tempered by this week's veg box installment: broccoli and purple kale. [caption id="attachment_614" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The good stuff "][/caption] Actually, I sort of am a steak-and-salad type of girl. Disappointing, I know. I like the chips and trimmings concept---who doesn't?---but I can't regularly polish off a fully-loaded plate. I'm the one who steals three chips from your plate, sips on water, while happily hovering up a side of rocket dressed with some shaving or other. Basically, my skinny jeans suit steak and salad. (Actually, they demand it.) The French fries just don't get a look in. I survived the two-steak and frittes servings experience at the Le Relais de l'Entrecôte in Paris---a former flame's gastronomic preference---and dutifully attempted to recreate their tarragon-laden buttery sauce, but I've never been back. For me, it's the type of meal that induces indigestion or immediate repose. [caption id="attachment_613" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Slicing the onion"][/caption] And, so this homemade affair was destined to be somewhat abstemious. Nevertheless, I left the butcher's with two prime cuts of fillet, and a spring in my step. Once home, I slowly caramelised onions with rosemary; seasoned the steaks; chopped the mandatory vegetables, and sipped on a G&T. [caption id="attachment_615" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly seasoned"][/caption] Aside from the style of serving, cooking steak seems a fraught affair. It's notoriously difficult to cook the meat exactly as requested. In this matter, the boy had little choice, I was aiming for medium rare, and medium on the side of rare was what we got. [caption id="attachment_617" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A few minutes on each side"][/caption] While steaks were cooking, I sauteed broccoli and kale with s splash of red wine vinegar and a teaspoon of freshly chopped red chilli. [caption id="attachment_616" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Slowly cooked"][/caption] The onions were slowly caramelising; a few minutes later, I removed the steaks, left them to rest; placed kale and broccoli aplenty on each plate, and scoured the fridge for mustard. The final result wasn't picture perfect, not by any means, but the meat tasted like butter, and then onions were sublimely sweet; my steak craving was satiated, and the boy was happy. (We feasted on sorbet for pudding; it was entirely restrained, of course.) [caption id="attachment_619" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption=" First impressions: tastes far better than it looks"][/caption] In these frugal times, even a steak lover finds a way to eek out another meal, so I'm looking forward to some kind of beef-themed seconds for supper tomorrow.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Aside from being delicious, this meal further reinforced the male stomach->heart theory.
Mouthwatering.

item.title: Simply supper
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Experience (sometimes bitter, yes) has taught me that skilful (successful?) baking is all about the measurements, the ingredients and the method; it's a precise art, and consequently reliable and safe. But, like every aspiring rebel, I occasionally like to break the rules; and throwing together a simple supper, with no recipe or regime to follow, enables me to enact my minor rebellion safely, with no fear of undercooked sponge or cracked meringues. [caption id="attachment_661" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Thrown together "][/caption] There were two stars of this show: the beef, and the Tuscan kale. My morning's forage (with a friend and her six month babe) to the nascent Saturday market at the Drill Hall, in Leith---where alongside pickled chutneys and locally laid eggs they're running a brilliant teach and mend service for those in need of some darning or bike repairs---furnished me with fresh Tuscan kale and the last of the summer's corn. [caption id="attachment_659" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="My favourite kale"][/caption] Like most things created on the hoof, our supper was a simple assemblage. Sliced vegetables, an onion and a good serving of fresh ginger were mixed together with thinly sliced beef that I'd marinated in some soy, finely sliced chilli, more fresh ginger, seasoning and a drop of honey. [caption id="attachment_655" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Marinading"][/caption] While the beef was softening and absorbing flavour, I prepped the veg. After that, it was simply a case of throwing it all in a hot pan. [caption id="attachment_657" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Beef, onion and leeks"][/caption] I removed the beef, briefly, from the pan to quickly cook the vegetables---who is a fan of overdone beef?---and then just mixed it all together for a further minute. [caption id="attachment_658" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Quickly stirfried"][/caption] Once cooked, we tucked in. Best leftover ingredient concoction I've eaten all month. [caption id="attachment_660" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Simply done"][/caption]

item.title: Almond marvel
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: As a dedicated almond-lover it's unsurprising---pretty predictable, really---that macaroons have been a favourite of mine for most of my life. It began as a weekly supermarket incentive---my mother's child-soothing toolbox did occasionally extend to sugary bribes---and is now a quieter lust, occasionally satiated by a Saturday morning stroll to a bakery. The chewy almond texture encased in a crunchy exterior has always appealed to my pronounced sweet tooth. Without any coconut, I hasten to add; those coconut-covered things that friends have devoured, I cannot comprehend. I am no desicated coconut lover. But things have become a little complicated of late: the ganache, buttercream filled sandwich style macaroon, epitomised by the delicate creations of Pierre Hermé in Paris, appeared to have rendered the simple macaroon passe. [caption id="attachment_721" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="An amateur attempt at a Parisian macaroon"][/caption] I loved that simple macaroon, and frankly it seemed an achievable baking feat. These new-fangled Parisian numbers are potentially too fussy for a standard kitchen dweller like me. Never one to overlook a challenge, however---even one where inevitable failure looms large---the almond frenzy began. David Lebowitz does not mince his words: "Tender, picture perfect macarons are not easy to make." It's the technique---therefore experience---not the recipe that matters. Not exactly inspirational words for a novice, but I steamed ahead regardless. These pesky sugar clouds would not put me off. What follows is more of a pictorial story, as there are far too many wonderful bloggers whose words and pictures convey the type of macaroon perfection I've yet to come close to achieving. Tarlette and Bakerella both eloquently describe and illustrate the process---I'd follow their approach, if I were to attempt this again. In addition, some of the pictures were taken by the boy, so credit is due to @andrewsenter for the almond action shots; essentially those where my hands appear in the picture... [caption id="attachment_702" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Sieving sugar and almonds"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_703" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Separating the yolk from the white"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_704" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Beating "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_706" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Pouring sugar and almonds into the egg white"][/caption] At this point I had no idea if I was on track, but I was enjoying the precise process. I was also happy not to have arrived at the "piping" portion of the recipe. I've never prided myself on being able to pipe mixture onto a tray in a perfect circular form. [caption id="attachment_707" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Mixing the paste until shiny "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_708" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Slowing piping macaroon mix"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_710" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Can amateur be artful? Learning to pipe in concentric circles"][/caption] Then I confused things by adding chocolate powder to the remaning mixture. The result was far closer to a speckled hen, than a Parisian macaroon, but I like to think they had a pretty charm in their own unique way. [caption id="attachment_712" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Chocolate speckled hens"][/caption] The macaroons then stood for an hour, attempting to gain an extra skin which adds to their chewy texture. I set about making a buttercream filling; a process I decided was infinitely more complicated than making the macaroons themselves. By adding boiling sugar to egg whites, the eggs are lightly cooked and then butter is beaten into the mixture. After that I added melted chocolate to the already devilish affair. [caption id="attachment_714" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Whipping warmed egg whites with sugar and chocolate "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_716" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Beating in butter and chocolate to make buttercream"][/caption] And then, once the macaroon pieces were cooled, the filling began. Of course, that's when I broke a few delicate shells and the boy was forced to sample them to assuage my seemingly distressed state. (It may have been an anxiety-ridden sugary state.) [caption id="attachment_717" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Creamed: adding chocolate goodness to a delicate shell "][/caption] [caption id="attachment_718" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="More cream, please"][/caption] One reflection, I had made enough buttercream to feed an army; I barely made any inroads into the bowl after generously filling twenty macaroon sandwiches. I even ate a tablespoonful; as did the boy surreptitiously on several occasions. I also contemplated a buttercream pie fight. The buttercream remained, glistening and rich in the fridge, no one has yet been assailed by the chocolate glop, yet. [caption id="attachment_719" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Not quite Parisian, but perfect for Edinburgh"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_720" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The final twenty "][/caption] Assembling the fragile macaroons required patience, and in the end they each had their misshapen charm. They were, however, delicious. Chewy and sweet. Creamy and moreish. They may have been a full evening's work, but they were eagerly devoured and, like all aspiring bakers, I intend to do a better job of them next time.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Always up for a bit of late night baking, but be warned - a week later, my sugar high is yet to subside.

What is a good (tested) french macaron recipe?... I've attempted David Lebovitz's recipe, so can certainly vouch for the above answer.  If you're looking for a fail safe approach, and a tutorial to macaroon-making you can't go wrong with Tartlette's article here: http://michiganmessenger.com/3241...

item.title: Just like granny used to make
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Under the weather---apparently a naval expression, pertaining to sailors who were sent below the deck to recover from sickness--is an apt way to describe my recent state. Making soup demanded all the culinary energy I had to muster. I'm unwaveringly loyal to my carrot, ginger and split pea concoction. My devotion to the glop knows no bounds: it's hearty, warming and utterly restorative. (It also nicely deals with the bendy carrots that have been neglected in the veg box.) It is not, however, pretty. No. This soup looks like gruel; and, as my colleague affectionately refers to it, smells like "granny soup". [caption id="attachment_766" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Warming: granny soup"][/caption] I'm not sure my granny ever  made soup like this. Perhaps, she dabbled with dried peas and lentils when my mother and uncle were little; I never knew to ask when she was around. She did grow her own carrots; beautiful sweet carrots, which always tasted better freshly picked than at the table---that generation had a habit of boiling vegetables until they were devoid of texture or flavour; hence the salt. Always a dollop, rather than a pinch, of salt. It was, in fact, a former flatmate who introduced me to the concept of dried peas, carrot and ginger. Nourishing, tick; economical, tick; delicious, tick. Oh, and very quick and easy to make. Staple fare for these austere times I'm thinking. Instead of ginger you could add chilli flakes, or even harissa paste, and for a richer, sweeter, consistency some coconut milk would be perfect. This time, I left the the soup as originally conceived: packed full of ginger, cumin and coriander. [caption id="attachment_763" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Toasted and ground"][/caption] The only preparation required is to lightly toast the cumin and coriander seeds for a few minutes in a pan. Then it's a case of slicing a large Spanish onion; mincing some fresh ginger; roughly chopping as many carrots as you have lurking in the kitchen; and simmering the split peas. [caption id="attachment_762" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Easily prepped: carrots and ginger"][/caption] This soup was partially an intervention---I hadn't been in the kitchen for nigh on a week---and so the boy kindly dragged me from my duvet-addled state and plugged me in at the stove. Small steps. This soup was my baby step. I only had to sauté the onions with the spices and carrots. [caption id="attachment_764" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sautéed: onions, carrots and a spice medley "][/caption] And that's really it. In one pan the peas were boiling, in the other a revitalising aroma of middle eastern spices were emerging; once combined the soup is done. It was, at this point, that the boy stood watch over the bubbling pea concoction, and I sat down ready to digest another serving of Mad Men (fully appreciating, of course, that no Mad Man would be guarding the soup while his other half reclined, resting, on the sofa). [caption id="attachment_765" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just add coriander "][/caption] Just before serving, when the consistency of the soup is akin to mud--sticky and thick--I added finely chopped coriander stalk, and then used the leaves and some spring onion for garnish. We ate. I'd made enough to guarantee I could avoid the kitchen for another day, if need be.

item.title: Soaking beans
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded:
The month before festive season commences, I like to to catch my breathe before too much tinsel and mince pie descend to wreak Yuletide havoc. Long dark evenings are the perfect excuse not to be overly active, to baton down the hatches, and indulge in slowly cooked warming suppers. Frankly, I need no excuse to retire to the kitchen (particularly as it's the warmest room in the house) and I'm pretty comfortable with the notion of seasonal hibernation, even if it's only as a preface to Christmas excess. Staying indoors allows me to catch up on neglected reading and engage in long overdue penmanship---I'm guilty of being a dire correspondent in the summer months---and it's also an opportune time to to make a bean stew. (Who wants to soak dried pulses when the sun's shinning?) [caption id="attachment_798" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Paprika and beans"][/caption] Melissa Clark's NYT piece about tender beans with sweet Italian sausage provided the inspiration, while a Saturday morning's ritualistic trip to the Edinburgh Farmer's Market provided the fodder. I tinkered with the recipe slightly, returning stocked with spicy venison sausages and cavalo nero. I was a tad flummoxed by the non-soaking aspect of the recipe, but since both the boy and I eagerly consumed several portions of the stew with no ill effects, it seems the requisite soaking of beans overnight is redundant if you cook the beans slowly, for several hours. [caption id="attachment_788" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly brown the meat"][/caption] Remembering an Italian-style sausage stew I had made before, I opted to remove the sausage meat from its casing and brown the naked meat. I could wax lyrical about these venison sausages for hours; they're slightly spiced and mixed with oatmeal, and on a cold autumnal evening offer delicious sustenance. For those less able to visit the market on a Saturday Fletchers of Auchtermuchty they're available to buy online and entirely worth it. (I'm partial to the dark chocolate and chilli variety as well.) [caption id="attachment_790" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bean, peppers, onions and herb ensemble"][/caption] Making this stew was so simple. After browning the meat, I cooked the vegetables---adding sweet peppers to the recipe---in a cumin and tomato paste. After that it was simply a case of adding the beans, a lot of water, some herbs and seasoning. It smelt too enticing; two hours is a long time to wait when there are such delicious aromas emanating from the kitchen. [caption id="attachment_792" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="FInal flourish: add kale and sausage to the pot"][/caption] I'd been craving a good serving of greens, so just before serving I added the roughly shredded cavalo nero along with the sausage pieces. A few more minutes cooking and we were done. Eager to eat after a day of outdoor autumnal activity. [caption id="attachment_787" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Perfectly hearty and filling: bean stew"][/caption] There was enough left to feed us for another few meals, although I made sure to hoover up more than my fair share in one sitting. When it comes to venison, how can gluttony be considered a sin? Recipe adapted from Melissa Clark's Dried Beans 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil, more for serving 1 pound sweet Italian sausage, sliced 3/4-inch thick 1 tablespoon tomato paste 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin 2 medium carrots, finely diced 2 celery stalks, finely diced 1 sweet pepper, finely sliced 1 onion, chopped 2 garlic cloves, finely chopped 1 pound dried white beans 2 teaspoons sea salt 2 teaspoons sweet smoked paprika 2 thyme sprigs 1 large rosemary sprig 1 bay leaf 2 teaspoons balsamic vinegar, more for serving 1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper, more to taste 1. Heat the oil in a large stockpot over medium-high heat. Add the sausage and brown until cooked through, about 7 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a plate lined with a paper towel. 2. Add the tomato paste and cumin to the pot. Cook, stirring, until dark golden, about 2 minutes. Add the carrots, celery, onion and garlic. Cook, stirring, until the vegetables have softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the beans, 8 cups water, salt, thyme, rosemary and bay leaf. Turn the heat up to high and bring to a boil. Then reduce heat to low and simmer gently until the beans are tender, about 2 hours, adding more water if needed to make sure the beans remain submerged.
3. When the beans are tender, return the sausage to the pot. Simmer for 5 minutes. Stir in the vinegar and pepper. Taste and adjust seasoning. Ladle into warm bowls and serve drizzled with additional vinegar and olive oil. Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

It's been blustery and dark outside all week and we've been breakfasting on the hoof; granola poured inelegantly into tupperware, a handful of almonds grabbed running out the door, or double espressos devoured outside the office steps (partially for warmth, mainly for the zing). [caption id="attachment_843" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Half a dozen oranges"][/caption] It may not be the weekend, but I've decided it's no excuse for a lack of indulgence; none at all. While the boy slept, I squeezed oranges, beat eggs, chopped parsley and listened to the less-than-soothing sound of George Osborne, attempting to defend the cuts. item.title: A kind of fish supper
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I don't usually confess to being inspired by TV shenanigans, but our weekend supper was certainly a derivation, if not a direct descendent, of Michel Roux Junior's eloquent production of stuffed sea bass with fennel. With one swift flourish, the Masterchef presenter gutted, descaled and filleted the fish; he removed the back bone without damaging the form, and as all experts do, he managed to make a difficult task seem effortless. I was not fooled, I knew my production would be short on such finesse. [caption id="attachment_868" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Removing the fins without finesse"][/caption] I've had minimal exposure to cooking a whole fish. Even at the fishmongers I'm more likely to opt for fillets (unless it's mackerel season) and all-too-aware of their customers' predelictions the mongers have already dispensed with the gills and the scales, removed the gut and cleaned the belly. It's all pretty sanitary after that. Nevertheless, our dearth of fishing skills notwithstanding, the boy successfully hunted and gathered (from the fishmonger) a whole (gutted) sea bass. He kindly left it on the kitchen work top for me to deal with... [caption id="attachment_863" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Waiting to be stuffed: sea bass"][/caption] I knew we'd be skipping the backbone removal, so Roux's creamy fennel and onion stuffing was replaced by panfried lemons and fennel leaves. We had some onions, fennel and lemon in the house, courtesy of our weekly delivery, and the aniseedy leaves were begging to be utilised as well. [caption id="attachment_867" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Panfried bed of fennel, onion and lemon "][/caption] After lightly panfrying the lemon slices, fennel and onion I arranged them as a bed for the fish to rest on. The plan was to cover the dish tightly with foil, steam the fish for about ten minutes, then remove the foil for a further five to crispen the skin and lightly roast the vegetables. The boy was drinking some light white wine, so I borrowed a small glass to add to the pan to ensure the fish wouldn't dry out. [caption id="attachment_876" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to roast: stuffed fish "][/caption] After overcoming the initial fear of fin removal---not a job I"m volunteering to repeat too soon---supper was sorted very quickly. The fish only needed 15 minutes in the oven, so I sautéed some cavalo nero and broccoli with some chilli and ginger and a dash of white wine vinegar. Then I waited. [caption id="attachment_877" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Perfectly cooked and ready to eat "][/caption] I may have expelled a small joyous squeal when I took the fish out the oven. It looked as I had hoped; it tasted better. The fish was infused with the flavours of fennel and lemon, enhanced by the sweetness of the onions. The boy filleted the cooked fish perfectly. It was so simple, but delicious. We devoured the lot, and saved the fish bones for some stock making. Baking a whole fish is entirely worth dealing with any ichthyophobia you may entertain.
