item.title: Ad hoc almond biscuits
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It's been grey and rain-filled for days. My hair---of the curly variety---has become a permanent frizz ball (fest?), deprived of sunshine, and reacting limply to the damp. I dream of Spain, of citrus fruit and almonds, picante chorizo and manchego; I crave the antithesis of late November. I steadfastly refuse to resort to whisky and a dour demeanour as befitting my adopted home. And so, when my fingers were red raw and numb and my groceries were drenched, I pictured lemon almond biscuits. They motivated me on my journey home. Crumbly, light and aromatic these were the biscuits I needed to make; while the rain fell on my face and my nose morphed into Reindeer's relation, I imagined myself creaming butter with sugar, adding lemon juice and zest to ground almonds. And so I did just that. The moment I got in the door. [caption id="attachment_914" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lemon and almond goodness"][/caption] I am no kitchen goddess---how did that become a comfortable part of our lexicon, Nigella?---but conforming to type I am a woman who retreats to the kitchen when it's cold outside. I care not how that pigeon-holes me (or whether that sentence even works) these biscuits were delicious and so simple to make. [caption id="attachment_909" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Creamed butter and sugar with almonds and zest"][/caption] I wasn't following a recipe as such, but your basic butter biscuit involves, sugar, butter, flour and an egg to bind. I substituted half the flour for ground almonds. When I ran out of ground almonds, the mixture was still looking too wet to form a good biscuit dough, the boy pulverised some almond flakes in the mortar and pestle. The texture was chunkier, the taste nutty and good. The zest of four lemons laced the mixture with a heady citrus scent. [caption id="attachment_912" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Browning in the oven"][/caption] The  biscuits took no time in the oven and tasted just as good piping hot, as they did cooled. The boy did not hold back; he keenly sampled the raw mixture, and tested each batch I took from the oven. I made four. [caption id="attachment_910" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The first batch "][/caption] The first test run produced a batch with slightly browned edges, but I lowered the temperature for subsequent versions, and reduced the portion size ever so slightly. [caption id="attachment_913" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Perfectly golden"][/caption] The second and third batches were much improved. By the fourth batch, having sampled at least three biscuits thus far, the question of what to make for supper was less pressing; I gathered the weekend papers, poured a glass of orange muscat and sat down with another biscuit. Still warm, how could I not? [caption id="attachment_929" align="aligncenter" width="392" caption="Batch number four"][/caption] As I write this, the kitchen is filled with biscuits. I suspect the Whitespacers will be offered an almond hit tomorrow, otherwise the boy and I will all too easily consume our body weight in lemon biscuits. (Then again, it's quite an appealing prospect...) [caption id="attachment_930" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="An excess of biscuits "][/caption]

item.title: Another parcel
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: For the lazy cook a parcel is the perfect cheat for supper---it's as close to a ready meal as you can get. Yes, there's a little bit of chopping and prepping to cover off---and some fiddly baking parchment folding to engage in---but that aside, it's a ready meal. Chop, wrap, bake, serve. As easy as that. [caption id="attachment_945" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Unwrapped: ginger salmon and vegetables "][/caption] I'm pretty keen on baked parcels; and I've written about them before, in greater detail, so I'm really just indulging my desire to post the pictures. And, also to announce that I'm over my fish sauce phobia. Over it. This time I added a tablespoon or so of fish sauce to the  marinade, and a dash of lemon juice---it was much improved. I also kept a bit of the chilli, ginger, soy and honey sauce to soak the salmon in. Even better. [caption id="attachment_944" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Chopped and prepped: vegetable bed with marinated salmon"][/caption] And that was it. Done. Salmon wrapped and lightly seasoned (no need for salt, really, as the soy-based marinade imbues the meal with a saltiness) I placed both fillets in a gratin dish at 200C for about 15 minutes. [caption id="attachment_946" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Simple supper"][/caption] The other advantage of the parcel (a bit like a stir fry) is it's a great way to disguise any maligned veg box goods; the boy is not keen on the savoy cabbage, but shredded and hidden by some rainbow chard and crunchy fennel it was easily disguised, and eagerly consumed. [caption id="attachment_947" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Served: just add coriander"][/caption] To borrow a phrase from Nigel Slater: it's a simple supper, keenly eaten. If there was enough Wild Atlantic salmon in the sea, I'd be eating this everyday.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: The parcel seems just my thing - easy, simple and nutritious. Like the idea of disgusing things - a useful tool when the fridge is overloaded with sell by dates.

We didn't eat it much at home when I was little; and my exposure was limited to a mild curiosity about the small pickled purple variety which I spotted in jars (next to the silverskins) in the supermarket aisles. They were as alien to me as a cornichon. Then I discovered fresh beetroot. Vibrant; versatile; and packed with health benefits (apparently) this urbanite is ashamed to admit I first encountered them in my weekly veg box, awash with mud, leaves still in tact. Baked, steamed, grated or blended, I've come to love the bulb as an accompaniment to fish and meat; and learnt to avoid wearing white clothing as the stains are a menace---who knew borscht could create sartorial casualties. Anyway, this time we made coleslaw with cabbage and carrots, but the colours dazzled me; no deep purple today, but bright pink and yellow---an antidote to grey skies and a winter's morning. item.title: Impromptu stew
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: What did people do before the freezer? Daft question, really. But on some evenings, that ice box is the closest thing  to a well-stocked pantry we've got; it's where I hide the gems I uncover on my urban foraging trips, but don't have room to consume that week. And that's how the mussels moved in. I've never had mussels in the freezer before, and it's only been a fortnight or so since the boy and I baulked at the notion of squid residing in our freezer à la Nigella, and then after a phone call with my mother, well, mussels made their way into the freezer. Apparently, they're rich in iron, manganese, phosphorous, selenium, zinc and vitamins C and B12; and in winter who can argue with that? Not my mother; and not, therefore, me. So, the mussels moved in (and brought squid and scallops for company). [caption id="attachment_991" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Fish stew"][/caption] Admittedly, the stew didn't quite turn out as I'd originally conceived; we'd ran out of the masala paste the boy had made a month or so before, and we didn't have any coconut cream, or milk, in the cupboard. Ordinarily a missing ingredient isn't a problem, but I wasn't in the mood for braving the snow blizzard: this meal was purely freezer and cupboard based. Toasting the spices was easy---we had all of those---and the smell in the kitchen was quite wonderful. [caption id="attachment_982" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Toasted: pan-fried spices "][/caption] Our coffee grinder---the hand-held variety---still had remnants of my decaf beans, and my inner sloth thought the mortar and pestle might be an easier approach; somewhat foolishly I overlooked the manual labour aspect of grinding. Nevertheless, the aroma was quite intoxicating, and I ploughed on. [caption id="attachment_984" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Spicing things up"][/caption] The base of the stew began, much like any other, with onions. You could add garlic here too; I didn't. The onions need to soften, rather than brown, as do the fennel and peppers. At this point I added the spices to infuse the mixture. [caption id="attachment_987" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Onions, peppers, fennel and tomato"][/caption] We didn't have a can of tinned tomatoes in the cupboard this time, but a combination of some chopped fresh cherry tomatoes, some tomato paste and hot water did the trick. (A cheat, yes---don't judge me too harshly, it works!) [caption id="attachment_990" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Water and curry leaves "][/caption] I added curry leaves and let the whole thing bubble. Next up: the mussels and prawns, and a squeeze of lemon juice. A touch more salt and pepper, and a quick stir. [caption id="attachment_989" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Almost ready to eat"][/caption] Ravenous, and ready to sit down and eat, I grabbed bowls, served up, and added a dollop of yoghurt. This may not have turned out quite as I intended, but I'll be making it as is, again and soon. [caption id="attachment_994" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to eat"][/caption] Impromptu fish recipe 3 tbsp cumin seeds 2 tbsp coriander seeds 2 tsp fennel seeds 2 tsp whole colves 2 tsp mustard seeds 2 tsp dried chilli 4/5 curry leaves 1 large onion, sliced 1 fennel bulb a dozen cherry, or plum, tomatoes 1 red pepper 1tbsp tomato paste 2 tbsp lemon juice 200g frozen, uncooked, seafood 200g frozen, uncooked, prawns salt and pepper Using a non-stick frying pan, lightly toast the spices---cumin, coriander, fennel and mustard seeds, cloves and chillis---but be careful not to burn them. When cooled, grind them with a mortar and pestle, until powdered, or opt for a coffee grinder for ease. Heat some oil in a large heavy-based pan over a medium heat. Fry the onions until soft; add the fennel and pepper slices, and cook for a further 5 minutes. Add the 2 tablespoons of the spiced powder mix and cook for a few more minutes. Add the chopped tomatoes; then the tomato paste, some salt and pepper and 1 1/2 cups of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium. Cover the pan and leave for about ten minutes. Add the seafood mix---we had mussels, squid and scallops---and prawns. Cook, uncovered, until the fish is cooked through - the prawns will turn a vibrant pink. It should be about 5 minutes. Ladle the stew into bowls.

item.title: A cookie for Christmas
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: My father is very particular about the Christmas tree. It's always a glorious height with luscious leaves; it's never put up before the 20th of December; and there's a strict silver and red decoration scheme. There are red and silver baubles, complementary candles, and a light dusting of silver snow. Two years ago I snuck some handmade parcels with ribbon onto the tree, but that's it. It always looks good; elegant and simple, but, secretly, I've always fancied a tree bedecked with iced gingerbread--a tad kitsch, I know---and as I still celebrate Christmas at the family home, it's a non-starter. The boy has vetoed Christmas-infused paraphernalia in the flat, so when there was talk of making decorations at work I rushed to volunteer my baking services. Gingerbread required? I'm there. And, so the recipe hunt began. [caption id="attachment_1063" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Cookie cutout"][/caption] I had quite a fixed concept in my head. I'd been raised on a diet of Lebkuchen--- iced cinnamon stars and chocolate coated all-spice infused cookies---so I craved a Germanic recipe, densely packed with cloves and nutmeg, as well as ground ginger. I wanted to taste the dense treacle richness of molasses, contrasted with the crunchness of demera, but I had no idea what I was doing... [caption id="attachment_1068" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Two types of sugar and some spice"][/caption] After much scouring of the internet, and researching the etymology of Speculaas I settled 0n a bastardisation of the St Nicoholas celebratory cookie. No cardamom or special mould, but it was a good base for an almond spiced biscuit. [caption id="attachment_1069" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Spiced mix"][/caption] Creaming the sugar and butter took longer than I had the patience for. The butter was probably too hard, and the sugar was obtusely textured---but, we got there in the end. I beat the eggs and added the ground almonds and flour. Somewhere along the way, however, I made a (rookie) mistake with the dough. [caption id="attachment_1061" align="aligncenter" width="527" caption="Cutting the shapes"][/caption] One recipe I found listed 7 cups of flour, but I had opted to follow the instructions detailing only 3 cups of flour---I had made more of a soup than a dough. Rescuing the dough was a two-step ordeal and the boy patiently assisted. We divided the mixture in two, adding more flour and ground almonds in batches; we then wrapped the dough in clingfilm and left it in the freezer for about 30 minutes. The result? A weightier, more malleable dough and one that I could work with. Phew. [caption id="attachment_1059" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Rows of stars"][/caption] It was a fiddly affair. I could only cut about 6 stars before the dough became too soft, and needed to return to the freezer for some quick chilling. Before baking, I pierced each star with the end of a chopstick, so we could thread them with string to hang them from the tree. [caption id="attachment_1062" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly baked, and ready to ice"][/caption] I was aiming to make 30 usable stars (one for each Whitespacer);  the boy and I could then gorge ourselves on the defective variants. I had intended to rise early and ice each one, but with so many creative types back at the office it dawned on me that the Whitespacers would be infinitely superior better icers---the ideal lunchtime activity. So I carried on cutting and baking until I had a full set of stars. And then I sat on the sofa to indulge in the lesser taxing task, sampling. Decidedly, not a bad way to spend a winter's evening. [caption id="attachment_1065" align="aligncenter" width="521" caption="Another batch"][/caption] Recipe 1 cup unsalted butter; softened 2 teaspoons vanilla extract 1 cup demerara sugar 1 1/4 cups molasses sugar 2 large eggs, lightly beaten 4 cups plain flour 1 cup ground almonds 2 teaspoons baking soda 2 teaspoons cinnamon 1 teaspoon nutmeg 1 teaspoon ground cloves 1 teaspoon ginger 1/2 teaspoon ground anise seed 1/8 teaspoon salt 1/2 cup sliced almonds In a large mixing bowl combine the butter and vanilla with both sugars and beat until light and fluffy. Add the beaten eggs and blend well. Sift the flour, the ground almonds and all the remaining dry ingredients together and beat into the butter mixture. Mix in the sliced almonds by hand, so as not to crush them. Divide the dough into two equal portions and if possible chill overnight. If you're short on time, pop the dough in the freezer for 30 to 45 minutes. Pre-heat oven to 170C. Roll the cooled dough out into 1/4-inch thick portions and cut with cookie cutters. Bake for 10-15 minutes, or until golden, cool on a wire wrack and then store in an airtight container.

item.title: A little chilli?
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I've nothing but respect for the ladies who pickle and preserve on a regular basis---in truth, I'd love to be a lass who comes home to a pantry full of home-made jam and chutney, but it hasn't happened yet. I don't think I'm equipped with the requisite patience to be a jam-maker. Struggling with Christmas gift inspiration this year, however, I decided to dabble in the kitchen with some chilli and tomatoes and see if I could conjure up anything resembling a chilli jam to eat with cheese or meat. (I'm partial to adding a few teaspoons of chilli jam when I'm making a stew.) If it tasted as pretty as it looked in the pan, this definitely had great gift potential; I'm thinking great aunts, or hospitable friends; too late for Secret Santa. [caption id="attachment_1139" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Making jam"][/caption] I must have read at least a dozen recipes before I settled on a variant I found in Delicious magazine; I liked the addition of ginger and spices, as well as sugar, chilli and garlic for flavour; I was also reassured by the simplicity of the recipe. [caption id="attachment_1134" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Chilli, ginger, onion and garlic "][/caption] In fact, once the spices were toasted and the various ingredients were chopped, there was very little to do---I just chucked everything in a heavy-based pan, and got busy sterilising the jars. (Drying the washed jars in the oven, meant sealing them was pretty hot and fiddly---I wouldn't recommend it, and need to finesse this stage somewhat next time.) [caption id="attachment_1135" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bring to the boil"][/caption] After about an hour of cooking the mixture was transformed into a sticky, jam-like substance. The kitchen was filled with an intoxicating aroma, but the piping hot steam emanating from the pan warned me off indulging my inner glutton and having a taste. [caption id="attachment_1137" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bubbling: not quite the rolling boil method"][/caption] After adding a splash of soy sauce, I let the mixture bubble for a little longer, and then removed it from the heat. After that, I spooned the hot mixture into the jars and waited for it too cool before having a taste. If the boy approves, I think I'll be making more for the cupboard; it's got a kick and a touch of spice and I'm thinking it'd be great on a bacon sandwich, as well as smothered over a goats cheese, salami and rocket panini. This jam-making thing isn't such a faff after all. [caption id="attachment_1138" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Cooked and cooled: ready to eat"][/caption] Recipe Adapted from Delicious magazine 2 tsp cumin seeds 2 tsp coriander seeds 750g ripe cherry tomatoes, halved 2 onions, finely chopped 2 garlic cloves, crushed 2 large mild red chillies, deseeded and finely chopped 10cm piece fresh ginger, grated 250ml white wine vinegar 300g soft light brown sugar 2 tsp soy sauce Method 1. Put the cumin and coriander seeds in a small frying pan and toast over a low heat for 1 minute, then crush in a pestle and mortar. 2. Put the tomatoes and onions in a wide pan with the garlic, chillies and ginger. Add the spices, vinegar and sugar. Bring to the boil, then simmer until reduced to a jam-like consistency. Add the soy sauce sauce and cook for 2 more minutes before spooning into sterilised jars. 3. Seal the jars while hot, then allow to cool completely before labelling and storing.

item.title: A New Year's sugar overload
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It's not often I get a pudding request---we're all so ostensibly busy we've reduced sitting down, conversing and digesting for more than one course to a strangely decadent occurrence---but sometimes occasion dictates a little lingering, a longer more indulgent meal with potential for unbuttoning of one's top trouser button to make room for the three courses. I was cooking New Year's supper for close friends, and one guest---an out-of-towner---was particularly keen on sampling a real English pudding. Sticky toffee, or spotted dick may have been more apt, but I settled on treacle tart, a peculiarly English affair: bread and golden syrup, certainly a bizarre combination. Only the English. (And Harry Potter---apparently he likes to snack on the sweet stuff.) [caption id="attachment_1185" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="All tarted up"][/caption] My tart was certainly a ramshackle affair; crumbly sweet pastry filled with sticky golden syrup with a hint of lemon. The lemon zest seems to cut through the extreme sweetness of the sugar filling. It's possibly the easiest pudding I've ever made. Once you cobbled together the pastry---feel free to cheat if needs be---it's a very straightforward affair and can be knocked together in a mere 15 minutes. [caption id="attachment_1182" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Cream, butter and lemon zest: just add golden syrup"][/caption] I didn't weigh the syrup, suspecting it might be a very sticky ordeal, but the recipe calls for about half a large tin (900g) so I guessed, and then it's a few tablespoons of cream, an egg, 30g of butter and the zest of two unwaxed lemons. [caption id="attachment_1183" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sugary goodness"][/caption] Once the syrup had been gently heated, I added the rest of the ingredients, swooning slightly at the thought of the arterial damage I'd be inflicting on my supper guests---the health benefits of treacle tart combined with potatoes dauphinoise and champagne have yet to be announced---and poured the sugar mixture into the pastry base. [caption id="attachment_1184" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready for baking"][/caption] After 30 minutes in the oven, the tart was ready to feast on. No one held back---somehow we all had enough room for two slices, topped with cream. [caption id="attachment_1186" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to eat "][/caption] Recipe (adapted from Tamasin Day Lewis's recipe) Pastry 180g plain flour 90g butter 2-3 tbsp ice-cold water Filling 1/2 a large tin of golden syrup 30g unsalted butter cut into small pieces 1 large egg, beaten 2-3 tbsp double cream grate zest of 2 unwaxed lemons 4 heaped tbsp breadcrumbs (white or brown) Put the flour and the cubed butter into a food processor and blend until you have what looks like fine breadcrumbs. (Do it by hand if you prefer, rubbing the butter into the flour with your fingers and thumbs.) Pour in the water, a tablespoon at a time, and mix again for a few seconds. Tip the dough out on to a lightly floured board, squeezing the dough to make a large ball. Wrap the ball in cling film and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes. Roll it out to fit the tart tin, pressing it into the edges. If you have the time leave the tin to rest in the fridge for half an hour. Set the oven at 200C.Take the tart case from the fridge, cover with baking parchment and any uncooked beans (or ceramic baking beads) to stop the pastry from puffing up, and bake for 15 minutes. Remove the beans and paper, prick the base with a fork and bake for a further 5 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside. Lower the heat to 180C. Warm the syrup gently, then, add the butter, take the pan off the heat and stir until all the butter has melted. Beat together the egg and cream and add to the syrup mixture; then add the lemon zest and breadcrumbs. Stir to mix evenly, and pour into the pastry case. Bake for 25-30 minutes, until dark golden and firm on top. Leave to cool for about 20 minutes, and serve with clotted cream, or ice cream.

item.title: Some kinda curry
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It's fairly easy to cheat at making curry. It doesn't always need to involve a labour of love, blitzing basil with lemongrass, or tamarind and fenugreek---the type of ingredients you know you've got to visit a specialist store to find---and last night, the corner shop had it all: ginger, a red chilli or two, and some coconut milk. Dare I say it? Easy. [caption id="attachment_1231" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Piping hot; ready to eat"][/caption] Currently it all seems to begin with an onion. Last night, I sliced two red onions, and left them to cook slowly, while I diced ginger, chilli and chopped up tomatoes. We had cumin and coriander seeds in the cupboard, so a quick bash in the pestle and mortar, and I added them to the pan. [caption id="attachment_1243" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Prepping: tomatoes, fennel and spice"][/caption] Once the onions looked done, I added the spices; swiftly followed by the vegetables and fresh chilli and ginger. Garlic fiends may want to add a couple of crushed cloves here. [caption id="attachment_1244" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Curry base"][/caption] When the tomatoes had softened and simmered, I added the lime juice, some water and the coconut milk. This is a rich curry, so you could use half a can of the milk, but omitting it altogether would negate the soothing effect of the milk on the piquancy of the chillis. [caption id="attachment_1230" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sauce: ready for the fish"][/caption] After about ten minutes I added the spinach, and then the prawns and salmon chunks, leaving them to bathe in a chilli and tomato infused broth of coconut milk. We didn't bother with rice, just an extra large serving, and a cold beer. Fresh coriander might be nice addition, I served it bare. And we gamely wolfed the lot. [caption id="attachment_1234" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Diving in: fish curry "][/caption] Recipe Some oil for the pan, groundnut if possible 2 large red onions, finely sliced 4cm piece of fresh ginger finely chopped 2 red chillies, deseeded and roughly chopped 1 tbsp ground cumin 2 tsp ground coriander 10 tomatoes, roughly chopped (you could supplement with a can of plum tomatoes if easier) 1 fennel bulb thinly sliced a generous handful of curry leaves 1 can of coconut milk 1/2 cup of water juice of 1 lime (optional) 150g baby spinach leaves, 200g raw king prawns 2 salmon fillets, cut in chunks Method Heat the oil in a frying pan over a low heat. Add the onion, season and cook for about 10 minutes until softened. Add the ginger and chilli along with the spices, cook for a further 5 minutes. When the kitchen is filled with a spicy aroma, add the fennel slices, the chopped tomatoes and curry leaves, bring to the boil and simmer for 5 minutes. Pour in the coconut milk, half a cup of water and lime juice, and leave to simmer over a medium heat for 10 minutes. Now add the spinach and cook until just wilted. Add the prawns and salmon and cook until the prawns are pink. Stir gently or the salmon pieces will break up. Serve with rice, or bread to mop up the rice sauce.

item.title: A taste for langoustine
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: January has been relegated to the month of monitoring waistlines and tightening pursestrings---never a bad idea in itself---to match the grey skies and post-Yuletide hangovers. And that's fine, most of the time. But when you're staring at a tray of fresh langoustine at the Farmers' Market on a Saturday morning it's hard to resist. I couldn't. [caption id="attachment_1259" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Langoustine languidly wait"][/caption] I've never cooked langoustine---or lobster for that matter---before, but having eaten it, I knew I wanted to keep things as simple as possible. The old guard---Elizabeth David, Julia Child et al---create fairly rich, ambitious recipes; I struggled to find a more basic variant until, courtesy of Twitter, a friend pointed me in the direction of grilling. [caption id="attachment_1260" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Butterflied"][/caption] I opted for butterflying the shellfish; whipping up a parsley garlic butter; and quickly grilling them under a medium heat. The boy kindly volunteered to do the manly work and remove the dirt and guts, while I set to whipping up some butter. Either salted or unsalted butter is fine for making herb butter. Just adjust the seasoning accordingly. If I'd had the time I might have hunted down some chervil and chives to add to the butter with the parsley for a more pungent flavour, but a few cloves of smoked garlic, finely chopped, a generous serving of fresh parsley and a good squeeze of lemon juice was flavour enough. Beating the butter turned out to be the most challenging part of preparing supper. [caption id="attachment_1262" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Prepped and decorated with butter"][/caption] The recipes I read recommended wrapping the remaining butter in clingfilm and serving the shellfish with wafer thin slices; so I duly did. I baked the langoustine for 2 mins at a high temperature, followed by 3 minutes under the grill. The kitchen was filled with a fantastic garlic aroma, and I was very ready to eat. We'd been fairly abstemious: only half a dozen langoustine each, quickly devoured. And, I'm certainly left with a taste for more. [caption id="attachment_1263" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to eat"][/caption]

item.title: Anti-austerity part deux
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: In line with remaining cheerful, and avoiding obilgatory detox diets and penny pinching, the boy and I have maintained our eat-well-throughout- January resolution pretty well. Last night we had duck. In fact, we've had duck three times this week: for supper, for the following night's supper, and then for lunch later in the week. We've become kind of attached to the duck. Or simply put, we've developed a pseudo-dependency on what eating the duck represents: the opposite of January. We did plough through two evenings of pauper's soup: water, celery, potatoes and cabbage; the overwhelming blandness punctuated only by the rich piquancy of a few chunks of chorizo---and then we abandoned such dull nutrition. [caption id="attachment_1305" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Duck with orange and star anise "][/caption] I cannot claim full authorship of the meal. I may have made the pomengranate molasses dressing, and sliced the cucumber and peppers, but the duck belongs to the boy. In fact, he first made a similar meal in the early hazy days of our dalliance: duck pour deux, history reveals I was impressed. Asparagus may have featured in his original version. But the rub was the same: an aromatic blend of star anise, cloves, orange rind, rosemary, salt and pepper; the duck gently seared, and served perfectly pink. [caption id="attachment_1302" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly seared"][/caption] It is a meal of minimal input for maximal flavour: it impresses and tastes delicious, but takes only minutes to prepare and less to cook.We caramelised the sauce slightly, experimenting with the consistency on each occasion. My favourite remains the simpliest: water, molasses, oil, salt and pepper; a touch of sugar if you prefer. [caption id="attachment_1300" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The makings of a sauce"][/caption] The duck breast needs only 6-8 minutes on or so, we cooked it skin side down on a high heat, and a further 3 minutes on the other side. Make sure you leave it to rest before you carve. [caption id="attachment_1304" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Perfectly pink, and rested"][/caption] Some may prefer their meat a little less rare---the end slices are always better cooked, and a little less bloody. Arrange the salad and the meat as you like---I opted for a scattered look, but stacked, or circular may appeal to the more fastidious---and drizzle with dressing or jus, whichever you prefer. [caption id="attachment_1301" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to gorge"][/caption] The first time I ate this, I could have eaten the same again, twice. The third time we ate it, we did. February will be a duck-free zone. Recipe Star anise rub 1 tbsp ground star anise 1 tbsp black peppercorns 1 tsp brown sugar 1 tsp ground cloves 1 tbsp sea salt 1 tbsp orange zest (optional) Pomegranate molasses dressing, adapted from a Moro recipe 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon 2 tbsp pomegranate molasses* 1 tbsp water 4 tbsp olive oil 1/2 tsp caster sugar seasoning Method About an hour before cooking, combine the star anise, peppercorns, cloves, sugar and sea salt in a small bowl and rub into the skin of the duck breast, place into a bowl, cover and allow to stand for 30 minutes. You could add orange rind if you have some.  Prepare the salad: leaves, spring onion, cucumber and peppers, finely sliced. Mango pieces would make a good alternative. Dress generously. Heat up a non stick frying pan over medium heat and seal the duck breast skin side down for 5-8 minutes and again on the other side, remove from the pan and allow to rest in a warm place skin side up. Slice thinly, and place on the dressed salad. * You should be able to find pomegranate molasses in your local Middle Eastern store, even your health food shop; and some supermarkets are beginning to stock it now too.

item.title: Simply Madelines, for Andrew
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I've had Pierre Herme's beautiful cookbook on my shelves for a fortnight now. The pages are filled with inspirational, tempting chocolate-themed deserts, the type of dish to lure you back into the kitchen after a baking hiatus, and leave you licking the mixing bowl clean. And yet, I've not made a thing. Not one. Each recipe requires a new ingredient, and the pictures are so perfect, and the method so detailed and complex, that instead of feeling inspired, I'm put off. But as I've recently acquired more time---and less projects---I did find myself wanting to bake. And as I've recently acquired a Madeline tray, courtesy of my mother, it seemed an easy option. There's always flour and eggs in my kitchen, and today I fancied the zing of ginger in my glorified fairy cake.  No other cake has been elevated to such lofty heights, as the slightly dry and strangely shaped Madeline, immortalised by Proust. [caption id="attachment_1357" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sweet enough to eat straight out of the oven"][/caption] The ingredients are the same as those we use in a standard fairy cake, but the method a little different. The eggs and sugar require beating separately for fluffiness, and the butter is melted. I added extra ground ginger and chunks of stem ginger for extra heat. A drop of vanilla extract to sweeten the mixture. And that was it. [caption id="attachment_1355" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Fold gently"][/caption] I read that the bump, or nipple as the boy christened it, was dependent on chill time. I cheated. 15 minutes in the freezer, and that was me done. [caption id="attachment_1356" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Melted butter to boot"][/caption] I broke all the rules and eagerly sampled the raw batter---delicious. It wasn't bad out of the oven either. The mould only held nine: not enough for more than the boy and me. I'll have to double it when I make it for friends for tea. [caption id="attachment_1358" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just enough for two"][/caption] Recipe 100g plain flour ½ tsp baking powder 2 tsp ground ginger 75g caster sugar 2 eggs 1 tsp vanilla extract 3 pieces stem ginger in syrup, finely chopped, plus 1 tbsp of the syrup 90g unsalted butter, melted Sift the flour, baking powder and ground ginger together with a pinch of salt. Whisk the sugar and eggs with electric beaters until they are thick and fluffy. Gently fold in the flour mix, vanilla and stem ginger and syrup. The add the butter, fold gently. If you have the time, cover the surface with clingfilm and chill overnight. If not, spoon the mixture, 1tbsp per shell, into a buttered Madeline mould and freeze for 15 minutes. Heat the oven to 200C/fan 180C/gas 6. Bake for 10 minutes or until risen and golden in colour. Tap the tin to loosen and tip out. Best served warm.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The easy option indeed; 11pm is no time to be reading Pierre, not if you want to sleep.
There's always tomorrow - perhaps with something from Moro as the main?

item.title: Just as Elizabeth used to make
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It is nearly the end of January. The evenings are slowly becoming longer, and the mornings a little lighter. Winter is nearly over, and I look forward, keenly, to Spring. I appreciate the romanticism of a white Christmas, but I am a sunshine girl at heart. So my daylight cravings were indirectly answered by the items in this week's veg box: purple garlic, courgettes, onions, peppers and aubergine; a sunny Mediterranean feast, that required Elizabeth David and a glass of wine. [caption id="attachment_1343" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="This week's delivery"][/caption] Supper was a simple rustic feast. The vegetable box dictated the theme, and the boy gathered the meat: lamb chops. [caption id="attachment_1346" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Prepped"][/caption] Ratatouille is distinctly unfashionable these days. Was it the fact that it became a canned option? Personally, I love the simplicity of the dish, the pungency of the garlic, and the way the vegetables are cooked until it seems they could almost collapse. But then, I've never had the pleasure---or pain---of the canned version. [caption id="attachment_1342" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Simply done: griddled"][/caption] Arguably making ratatouille does require time. If you adhere to the Richard Olney method, you're looking at four or five pans, each vegetable cooked separately and only fused together at the end, I prefer the ragout approach. It's simple, and perfectly delicious. When it comes to making ratatouille, Elizabeth David is a purist. Her recipe instructs nothing but onions and garlic seeped in oil, with aubergine, peppers, courgettes and tomatoes added slowly as each softens. The vegetables must not fry, but stew in the oil, cooking with the lid for around half an hour. She adds no herbs. Perversions---is that too harsh?---of the recipe indulge in pan-roasting; apparently to reduce the amount of oil without affecting the flavour on grounds of health. I'm not buying. [caption id="attachment_1340" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="One pot approach"][/caption] So I dutifully followed David's advice and was generous with my lashings of olive oil. The onions slowly sweated and cooked; one by one, I added the rest of the colourful vegetable medley. While the ratatouille was cooking, I prepped the lamb with salt, pepper and rosemary. I sipped my glass of Merlot, and enjoyed the heady aroma filling the kitchen. [caption id="attachment_1345" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Done"][/caption] Supper was done. We ate fast, and enjoyed every bite. I declined seconds, hoping to save some for another meal. There is not enough ratatouille in my life; Spring, however, is nearly here. [caption id="attachment_1348" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Plated and ready to eat"][/caption] Ratatouille recipe, adapted from Elizabeth David's Mediterranean Food, French Country Cooking 2 large Spanish onions 2 aubergines 1 courgette 2 red peppers 4 ripe tomatoes (or a can of tinned tomatoes) 2 cloves garlic oil salt and pepper Peel the tomatoes and cut the aubergines into squares. Slice the onions and peppers finely. Put the onions and garlic cloves into a heavy-bottomed sauté pan with plenty of oil; cook on a medium heat. When the onions have softened add the peppers, and the aubergines. Cook for five minutes and add the courgettes. Then, around five minutes later, add the tomatoes. The vegetables should be stewing in the oil, so simmer in a covered pan for around 30 minutes. Remove the lid, cook for a further five minutes and serve.

item.title: How much dairy did you eat last night?
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: No matter how I feel I know that onions cooked in oil will always soften and turn a beautiful shade of translucent white; if I add fennel the mixture becomes infused with an aniseedy tang, and if I add ginger, well ginger adds the zing. Whatever my mood, in the kitchen I can always create something. I know that sugar and eggs added to whipped cream cheese will become a soft, oozing mixture; and once cooked, a delicious, light moreish cheesecake. In the kitchen it's that simple. [caption id="attachment_1407" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Over a kilo of dairy"][/caption] And cheesecake has been on my mind. So, on a rainy Tuesday evening, instead of pounding the pavements and improving my fitness, I beat eggs and cream cheese (with a healthy serving of mascarpone) and probably improved my cholesterol levels no end. It all started with some ginger biscuits. [caption id="attachment_1405" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bashed biscuits"][/caption] I was hankering for simple New York cheesecake, rich and tangy with a gingery base. Who better to follow than Dorie Greenspan and her marvellous Baking with Dorie recipe series.  I love the notion that a world-renowned chef  encourages amateur bakers across the globe to bake her recipes by her regular blogging and support for ventures like Tuesdays with Dorie. [caption id="attachment_1406" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Butter, biscuits and a little lemon "][/caption] Her instructions seemed foolproof, so I began bashing my biscuits to make a base. I cheated slightly, minimal sugar as my ginger nuts were sweet enough, and I added a little lemon zest. The base seemed a little thin, and I didn't make enough to coat the sides, as Dorie recommends, but it smelt glorious after 10 minutes in the oven. Next up the cream cheese mixture. Again, her method was clear. A series of beatings for four minutes, adding sugar and eggs at various intervals. I began. [caption id="attachment_1408" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Stage one "][/caption] Thoroughly beaten, I added the sugar, salt and drop of vanilla extract. I also added zest of half a lemon, some of which I later lost to the beaters. Oh well. [caption id="attachment_1424" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A dash of citrus"][/caption] At this point, I was beating nigh on a kilo of dairy, but Dorie demanded more. Four large eggs and some sour cream. I ploughed on. [caption id="attachment_1410" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The third egg"][/caption] The mixture was becoming thicker, velvety and smooth. And there was so much of it; so much dairy in one bowl. A deluge, perhaps. The last hurdle was getting mixture into the tin. I'd already made my first mistake---I'd omitted to double wrap the base of the tin with foil. Apparently this is essential. [caption id="attachment_1411" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Poured"][/caption] There stood before me a satiny---is that a word?---mass of white liquid, fragranced with lemon and vanilla. It was a delicate feat getting the tin into the water bath---essential according to Nigella---and then manoeuvring the water and dairy-filled roasting tin into the hot oven. It had calamitous potential; but not a drop spilt. [caption id="attachment_1433" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Fresh from the oven "][/caption] Dorie instructs the baker to leave the cake for an hour in the water bath with the oven door ajar after it's cooked for 1 1/2 hours. It then has to cool before being refrigerated. It was nearly midnight before the cheesecake made it into the fridge---note for next time, start cooking before 8pm. [caption id="attachment_1434" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The morning after"][/caption] 8 hours later I removed the cake from the fridge, unlocked the springform, and despite the breakfast-hour eagerly cut a slice, or two. It may not have looked picture perfect---it had a rustic charm---but nothing has tasted creamier without feeling rich or heavy; the slight tang from the citrus, complemented the cheesy sweetness, I dug in. I may have eaten more than two slices for breakfast. I didn't keep count. Oh, and do use the foil. The base lost some of its crunch due to a little bit of seeping water---it's worth the extra effort. [caption id="attachment_1435" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A little rough around the edges, but tasty"][/caption] Recipe - based on Dorie Greenspan's Creamy cheese cheesecake For the base: A packet of ginger nuts, bashed 1 tbsp sugar Pinch of salt 1/2 stick (4 tablespoons) unsalted butter, melted For the cheesecake: 2 pounds (four 8-ounce boxes) cream cheese (or half mascarpone), at room temperature 1 1/3 cups sugar 1/2 teaspoon salt 2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract 4 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/3 cups sour cream Method Butter a 9-inch springform pan and wrap the bottom of the pan in a double layer of aluminum foil; put the pan on a baking sheet. Stir the crumbs, sugar and salt together in a medium bowl. Pour over the melted butter and stir until all of the dry ingredients are uniformly moist. Turn the ingredients into the buttered springform pan and use your fingers to pat an even layer of crumbs along the bottom of the pan and about halfway up the sides. Don't worry if the sides are not perfectly even or if the crumbs reach above or below the midway mark on the sides—this doesn't have to be a precision job. Put the pan in the freezer while you preheat the oven. Centre a rack in the oven, preheat the oven to 180C and place the springform on a baking sheet. Bake for 10 minutes. Set the crust aside to cool on a rack while you make the cheesecake. Reduce the oven temperature to 160C. Put a kettle of water on to boil. Working in a stand mixer, preferably fitted with a paddle attachment, or with a hand mixer in a large bowl, beat the cream cheese at medium speed until it is soft and lives up to the creamy part of its name---this should take about 4 minutes. With the mixer running, add the sugar and salt and continue to beat another 4 minutes or so, until the cream cheese is light. Beat in the vanilla. Then add the eggs one by one, beating for a full minute after each addition—you want a well-aerated batter. Reduce the mixer speed to low and stir in the sour cream. Put the foil-wrapped springform pan in the roasting pan. Give the batter a few stirs with a rubber spatula, just to make sure that nothing has been left unmixed at the bottom of the bowl, and scrape the batter into the springform pan. The batter will reach the brim of the pan. (If you have a pan with lower sides and have leftover batter, you can bake the batter in a buttered ramekin or small soufflé mold.) Put the roasting pan in the oven and pour enough boiling water in to come halfway up the sides of the springform pan. Bake the cheesecake for 1 hour and 30 minutes, at which point the top will be browned (and perhaps cracked) and may have risen just a little above the rim of the pan. Turn off the oven's heat and prop the oven door open with a wooden spoon. Allow the cheesecake to luxuriate in its water bath for another hour. After 1 hour, carefully pull the setup out of the oven, lift the springform pan out of the roaster—be careful, there may be some hot water in the aluminum foil—remove the foil. Let the cheesecake come to room temperature on a cooling rack. When the cake is cool, cover the top lightly and chill the cake for at least 4 hours, although overnight would be better.

item.title: Dabbling in pork
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I don't eat a lot of pork. I'm not sure why. I think it conjures up memories of very dry roast pork eaten unwillingly, but politely, at elderly relatives houses. So pork got shunted off the foods-I-like-to-eat list. Sure, it features in the odd sausage---mainly in the guise of chorizo---and I'm not one to turn down a thin slice of parma harm, but pork chops, pork fillet, even bacon; they're not regulars at my table. But someone I follow on Twitter---yes, that microblogging site does influence me, on occasion---kept posting about pork scratchings. He makes his own. Amazing. Noting the potential arterial damage, I opted for a lighter pork meal: tenderloin with some braised fennel. [caption id="attachment_1464" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Pork: with fennel and coriander seeds"][/caption] The recipe was simple: a fennel seed encrusted tenderloin roasted atop a bed of fennel. It took only minutes to prepare, and less than 15 to cook. [caption id="attachment_1462" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Braising fennel"][/caption] I was short of skillets and stock---I added extra wine, and used a much smaller pan. It was a bastardised braising method, but the fennel softened, and the butter bubbled. It smelt enticing. [caption id="attachment_1463" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Browned"][/caption] As usual, the meat needed to be browned before roasting; a few minutes on each side in a pan with a little oil. You could use the same pan to then braise the fennel---some of the pork juices, and the bashed fennel seeds would enhance the flavour. [caption id="attachment_1461" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Pork, cooked"][/caption] I placed the tenderloin on top of the braised fennel in a gratin dish; if using a skillet, you could put the pan in the oven and save on washing up. The boy likes his meat slightly pink, so I cooked the pork for just over ten minutes, removed it and left it to stand. [caption id="attachment_1460" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A plate of pork"][/caption] I wanted to caramelise the sauce slightly, so returned the fennel and juice to the pan, added a little lemon juice and a touch of brown sugar to the fennel and placed it on a high heat; a basic jus. Supper was pretty simple: a generous serving of sliced pork served on a bed of fennel. Simple, but delicious. I'm a pork convert.

item.title: Duck, done a bit different
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: Duck may have become our favourite meat of late. The boy has a special affection for a star anise rub, which we recently ate with a fennel, beetroot and orange salad---pretty hard to top---but last night's version was something else. Sticky, and seriously delicious. And simple. [caption id="attachment_1486" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Panfried: ginger duck"][/caption] Prepping and cooking this dish took under half an hour, which makes it an ideal midweek supper, aka the 30-minute meal. The marinade is basic, just some soy, rice vinegar and ginger syrup. If you don't have stem ginger in syrup in your cupboards, you could try honey with some ground ginger: it'll have a similar taste. [caption id="attachment_1484" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Chopped veg"][/caption] The veg we used was half Phantassie delivery and half corner shop - a mix of seasonal and local. You could certainly substitute with your own preferences; but, I'd skip the baby corn and mange tout medley. [caption id="attachment_1483" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Griddled: gingery duck"][/caption] The next steps are easy: cook the duck on a high heat. The boy has a nice Le Creuset griddle pan for these purposes, but any heavy-based pan would be fine, if you have a skillet try that. Everyone likes their meat done differently; the boy and I enjoy the lightly pink variety, so we cooked the duck for less than ten minutes. The more cautious may require a few minutes more. Leaving the duck to rest is important; about 10 minutes will do. I never really understood the exact science behind resting meat, but it allows the juices to redistribute and ensures nothing is lost when you slice it. [caption id="attachment_1485" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Lightly stir fried "][/caption] While the meat is resting, cook the veg. It takes very little time. Pour the leftover marinade into a small saucepan, bring to the boil, and reduce. When the bok choy begins to wilt, remove the wok from the heat and plate the mixture. I tried to make it look pretty, I failed. Be generous with the duck---place several slices on top of the vegetables and drizzle with the caramelised marinade. Serve and enjoy. I could have eaten both plates, and then some. [caption id="attachment_1487" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Duck pour deux "][/caption] Recipe 1 duck breast 3 tbsp soy sauce 3 tbsp stem ginger syrup (from a jar of stem ginger) 1 tbsp rice vinegar 1 tsp sesame oil Bok choy Asparagus Half a fennel bulb, sliced Red onion, sliced 1 tsp of diced stem ginger Combine the duck breast, soy sauce, rice vinegar, and stem ginger syrup in a bowl. Mix well to combine and chill in the fridge for at least 10 minutes. Heat the sesame oil in a griddle pan over a medium heat. Remove the duck breast from the marinade and fry, skin-side down, for 5-6 minutes, or until the fat is released. Keep the marinade. Turn the breast over over and cook for a further 4-5 imnutes or until cooked to your liking, then remove from the pan and set aside to rest. While the duck is resting, cook the vegetables in a wok. On a high heat, add sesame oil and the onions and ginger. Cook for 2 minutes and then add the fennel and asparagus. When the asparagus softens---about 4 minutes---add the sliced bok choy and cook for just under 2 minutes, until near wilting. Pour the leftover marinade into a small saucepan and bring ot the boil---it will caramelise slightly. Slice the rested duck thinly and serve on top of the stir fried vegetables; drizzle with the caramelised sauced. To serve, slice the duck breast and serve with the stir-fried bok choy.

item.title: Quick cassoulet
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It's a distinctly middle class dilemma when you can't find sweet Italian sausages on a Sunday. But foraging in the cupboards produced potential: smoked garlic, a chorizo sausage, onions, a dozen or so tomatoes and thyme. Oh, and the drinks cabinet---as such that we have one---holds sherry as a staple. I had wanted to make something along the lines of Richard Olney's Cassoulet in his French Menu Cookbook---but if I failed to purchase sweet Italian sausages, I was unlikely to stumble upon goose fat and lamb that went alongside the garlic sausage and other ingredients. So I took the easy way out---no recipe and a medley of ingredients. [caption id="attachment_1520" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Chopped: chorizo"][/caption] There's a wonderful recipe for chorizo cooked with sherry in the Moro cookbook. I'm easily influenced, so I corrupted a strictly French recipe and threw in some Spanish themes. While the chorizo bathed in a generous serving of sherry, I chopped onions, carrots, celery and garlic. The garlic was yellowing at the edges, a hint at its smoked nature; the smell was almost sweet. [caption id="attachment_1515" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="From board to pan"][/caption] After about 5 minutes of sizzling chorizo, I added the veg and left them to soften slowly. I chopped the tomatoes and grabbed the thyme and sage to add to the pot. Cassoulet might call for a few glugs of red wine, but I was sticking to the sherry---I poured another half cup into the pan, and added a couple of drops of Vinagre de Jerez. Good smells emanated. I switched on the oven - around 200C should do. [caption id="attachment_1516" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Sizzling"][/caption] Next up a dozen or so chopped tomatoes---a can or two would do---and 4 tbsp of pasata. I placed the lid on the pan and left the mixture to cook for 10 minutes. If you were diligent, you could soak beans overnight; as this was a cupboard supper, I rinsed a can of borlotti beans and added them to the mix. [caption id="attachment_1518" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Bubbling away"][/caption] The beans only need a few minutes in the pan---they'll cook plenty in the oven---so I added them as the final flourish and removed the pan from the heat. To save on washing up, you could do this all in a roasting pan, but I transfered the mix to a large gratin dish and laid a dozen sausages on top to ensure they browned nicely as they cooked. [caption id="attachment_1519" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Add sausages and ready for the oven "][/caption] Halfway through cooking I turned the sausages to ensure they were fully browned; if you were busy doing something more interesting you could leave the dish untouched for 40 minutes. Serve immediately, and enjoy. [caption id="attachment_1533" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready to eat"][/caption] I'm somewhat ashamed to admit we ate enough for four people. There was only one portion leftover for lunch; suspect someone may have availed themselves of a midnight snack. Edit: recipe as requested Recipe 1 chorizo sausage extra virgin olive oil 1 large bunch of mixed fresh thyme and sage 2 red onions, peeled and roughly chopped 2 cloves of garlic, chopped (I used smoked) 1 large carrot, peeled and roughly chopped 2 sticks of celery, finely chopped 2 bay leaves 1/2 a cup of sherry 1 can tinned plum tomatoes 1 can of borlotti beans 12 chipolata sausages salt and pepper Pre-heat the oven to 180C. Use a wide casserole dish or roasting tin. Slice the chorizo into thin pieces and fry. You don't need to add oil as the chorizo will release its own. After about 4 minutes when the piece are being to crisp, add half the sherry. Leave to cook for about 5 minutes. Tie your herbs together with some string and add to the chorizo in the pan with your onions, garlic, carrot, celery and bay leaves.  Add the remaining sherry and half a cup of water. Add the tomatoes to the pan, breaking them up with a spoon. Leave to simmer for ten minutes. Now add the bean and bring to the boil. Lightly season with salt and pepper before laying your sausages on top — all higgledy piggledy. Place in the oven for around 1 hour. Serve straight from the dish and enjoy.

item.title: When life gives you lemons make cupcakes
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I can't remember why I felt compelled to whip up a batch of sugary citrus-themed goodness. The freedom of a freelancer means you can steal away from your desk---in my case, located a mere five few feet from the kitchen---and break some eggs in time for afternoon tea. Bliss. Cupcakes were fairly fashionable until they were ousted by the macaron, recently elevated to an art form by Pierre Herme. Anyway, when the cupcake was still in vogue and people were lining the streets waiting to sample them (or is that only in New York?) the Hummingbird bakery opened. My sister raves about their red velvet variety, but I'm a fan of simple flavours, and lemon suits me best. [caption id="attachment_1558" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A stack of cupcakes"][/caption] When we were little, we made fairy cakes---cupcakes in their former guise---for fetes, school bakes sales and birthdays. My mother was mistress of the magimix and the recipe was simple: equal amounts of flour, sugar and butter with two eggs. Mary Berry's approach was foolproof---my mother makes no claims to be a baker. [caption id="attachment_1550" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ingredients laid out"][/caption] The Hummingbird recipe was a little fussier than the fairy cakes of old, but the result was more impressive. The cupcakes were light (even two days later) and the icing moreish. Less egg and more milk seems to be the secret. [caption id="attachment_1552" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just add milk"][/caption] When the flour, butter, sugar and lemon zest resembled sand, I added milk. The mixture became more malleable and after a little more beating, I added the egg. [caption id="attachment_1553" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just one egg"][/caption] We were done. I spooned the mixture into the cases---the boy licked the bowl---and I popped the tray into the oven. [caption id="attachment_1554" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Spooning "][/caption] Making the icing wasn't fussy. A bit of beating, some tasting and then some spooning. The recipe calls for food colouring---I kept it au naturel---and left out the extra lemon zest as decoration. [caption id="attachment_1557" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Cooling and almost ready to eat"][/caption] I was generous with the icing, no point in skimping on the sugar hit at this stage. The cupcakes didn't last long and made a delicious breakfast. I could have survived on just the icing. [caption id="attachment_1592" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Ready"][/caption] Recipe, adapted from the Hummingbird Bakery recipe Cupcake: 120 grams plain flour 150 grams caster sugar 1 1/2 teaspoon baking powder 2 tablespoons grated lemon zest (plus extra to decorate) 40 grams unsalted butter, at room temperature 120 ml whole milk 1 egg Lemon icing: 250 grams icing sugar, sifted 80 grams unsalted butter, at room temperature 2 tablespoons grated lemon zest Juice of 1/2 lemon 25 ml whole milk Method Preheat the oven to 170°C/325°F. Put the flour, sugar, baking powder, lemon zest and butter in a bowl and beat on low speed until you get a sandy consistency and everything is combined. Gradually pour in the milk and beat until just incorporated. Add the egg to the flour mixture and continue beating until just incorporated. Continue mixing for a couple of minutes until the mixture is smooth. Spoon the mixture into the paper cases until 2/3 full - they will rise in the while cooking. Bake in pre-heated oven for 20-25 minutes or until the sponge bounces back when touched. A skewer inserted should come out clean. Leave the cupcakes to cool slightly in tray before turning out onto wire cooling rack to cool completely. For the frosting beat together the icing sugar, butter, lemon zest, lemon juice and food colouring on medium-slow speed until the mixture comes together and is well mixed. Turn the mixer down to a slower speed. Slowly pour in the milk, then when it is all incorporated, turn the mixer up to high speed. Continue beating until the frosting is light and fluffy (at least 5 minutes). When the cupcakes are cold, spoon the lemon frosting on top and eat.

item.title: Sometimes I fancy fritters
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: One of the things I'll miss most about this town---aside from the architectural beauty---when I return to London, is the plethora of independent delis dotted around town. There are three a stone's throw from my doorstep, purveying handmade sausage rolls with caraway-infused puff pastry, delicious almond and orange cakes, or unusual generously-iced pistachio cupcakes. And, all for a decent price. I won't be so lucky in London. One store, Broughton Deli always has a tantalizing quiche or baguette on offer. And, last week their pea and sweetcorn fritters caught my eye. Greasy, moreish and delicious, I definitely wanted to recreate it in my own kitchen. [caption id="attachment_1604" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="All you need for a fritter"][/caption] I'd never made a fritter before, but it looked like a simple feat. I read a couple of recipes before tackling it freestyle---the only point of difference was whether to include some feta in the mix as well. I opted to go without. [caption id="attachment_1606" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Into the frying pan "][/caption] The batter took only minutes to prepare. For the first run I stuck with parsley, onions and pepper for flavour, but the second innings featured spring onions and a little fresh chilli for a kick. I lef the batter to stand for 15 minutes, warmed the pan and crossed my fingers. I am not the world's most accomplished pancake-maker, and feared fritters could go the same way. [caption id="attachment_1607" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Golden brown"][/caption] I left the fritter to cook for 3 minutes and flipped it. I lost a kernel or two of corn along the way, but for a first attempt it wasn't too flakey. As my large frying pan was otherwise occupied, I was making the fritters in single batches in a small omelette pan---I'd definitely recommend working with a larger pan; it gives you more room to flip; an integral part of the process. [caption id="attachment_1608" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Cooked, and warming "][/caption] The great thing about fritters is they contain reassuringly healthy ingredients---I didn't feel full of grease despite gorging myself on at least three. They are so quick and simple to make, and pretty economical too; a bag of frozen corn ain't going to break the bank. [caption id="attachment_1611" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Perfect with a little salad"][/caption] This morning I made them for breakfast. With bacon on top. As I write, I'm thinking about the lunch options. Recipe, inspired by Bill Granger 1 cup plain flour 1 teaspoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon sweet paprika 1 tablespoon sugar 2 large eggs 2 cups (from 2 to 3 ears) corn kernels 1/2 cup red pepper, cut into small dice 1/2 cup red onion, finely diced 2 tablespoons chopped parsley 2 tablespoons vegetable oil Sift the flour, baking powder, salt and paprika into a medium bowl. Add the sugar, stir to combine, and make a well in the center of the dry ingredients. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs and milk until combined. Gradually add the egg mixture to the dry ingredients and whisk until a smooth, stiff, lump-free batter forms. Stir in the corn, pepper, onions and parsley. Leave to stand for at least 10 minutes. In a large frying pan, heat the vegetable oil over medium heat. When the oil is hot, add the batter (around 2 tablespoons), cooking four at a time. Fry for 2 minutes or until the underside of each fritter is golden. Turn the fritters over and cook until the other side is golden. Transfer to another plate and keep warm while cooking the remaining fritters.

item.title: A laksa full of scallops
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: For years I had an irrational fear of seafood---it's still not entirely cured. I've tried oysters once---in the living room of a chef---and I'm still not a convert; mussels and I get along ok when served in a coconut broth and I've successfully sampled scallops a few times. I think it comes down to texture, rather than origin. Irrational, I know. I was passing our local fishmongers and spotted the juicy scallops nestled alongside the swordfish steaks---in the mood to break the everyday, I braved my phobia and purchased a dozen. From what I've read, scallops are delcious with Oriential flavours like chilli and ginger; I decided to experiment with a coconut laksa. [caption id="attachment_1619" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Seared"][/caption] If you have the time, it's worth making a trip to an Asian grocer to get the ingredients for this heart- and limb-warming broth. If not, it's ok to skip the odd ingredient; this isn't Masterchef, no one is judging you here... [caption id="attachment_1617" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Colourful beginning"][/caption] Although there are a lot of ingredients, the recipe is straightforward, adding layer upon layer of spices and flavours to create the broth. Once the ginger, chilli, garlic et al have cooked, you add the coconut milk and water, leaving the mixture to simmer for around 40 minutes. The aroma took me straight back to the streets of Bangkok. [caption id="attachment_1618" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A touch of purple kale"][/caption] Our weekly veg box delivery had included purple kale, so diverting slightly from the recipe and style of laksa I added a generous handful to the pot. While the mixture simmered, I seared the scallops lightly as instructed - be careful not to overcook them, it's easily done. Plating is easy - be generous with the broth and top with the scallops, sliced in half. [caption id="attachment_1620" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Plated: ready to eat"][/caption] Recipe 1 red onion, peeled and sliced 2 cloves garlic, crushed 50 g ginger, unpeeled, sliced sesame oil, for frying 1 red chilli, finely sliced (use more or less to taste) 4 lime leaves 1 small bunches coriander, with roots 2 black cardamom, roughly chopped 2 star anise, broken up 1/2 tsp fennel seeds 1 lump pale palm sugar, chopped 4 tbsp fish sauce 1.2 litres coconut milk 25 g tamarind paste 50-100 ml lime juice 12 scallops 2 spring onions, finely sliced 1. Heat a large pan and lightly caramelise the onion, garlic, galangal and ginger in 2 tablespoons of sesame oil. Add 2/3 of the chilli, the kaffir lime leaves and the roots and stems of the coriander (pound them first to release the flavours). Stir in the spices  and cook over a medium heat for 3-4 minutes, stirring often. 2. Add the palm sugar, nam pla, coconut milk, tamarind and 600ml hot water and bring to the boil. Turn down to a simmer and cook for 40 minutes, stirring occasionally. 3. Add more nam pla, some lime juice and the squeezed lime halves. Leave to simmer while you assemble the rest of the dish. 4. Toss the scallops in a little sesame oil then sear in a really hot pan to colour the outsides, but do not cook beyond rare. Rest for a minute then slice in half horizontally. 5. Warm 4 deepish bowls. Ladle over the laksa broth and sit the seared scallops on top. Scatter with the reserved chilli slices, spring onions and the coriander leaves.

item.title: Whipping up more egg whites
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: I'll do anything to avoid packing. The last week has been filled with box-related activities. Scavenging for boxes, filling boxes and moving boxes---our lives have been neatly packaged and put away. I had a hankering to bake, and I found some amaretto lurking in the cupboard, begging to be used before we moved. Separating egg whites from yolk seemed like a a perfect way to pass the time, a legitimate excuse to avoid the endless packing and cleaning. [caption id="attachment_1654" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="An array of shapes and sizes"][/caption] A lot of noise is made about the difficulty of meringue-making, but it's always seemed relatively straightforward to me. That said, I'm not aspiring for perfection---my meringues are a motley crew, all shapes and sizes. Ottolenghi recommends baking the sugar slightly, so the egg white is slightly cooked. Apparently this improves the texture. I accidentally caramelised two batches of sugar in the oven along the way. [caption id="attachment_1649" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Stiff whites"][/caption] Other than the cooked sugar, the method is exactly the same---beat whites, add sugar, and wait until they are glossy and stiff. I added a few drops of amaretto near the end, just for a bit of kick. [caption id="attachment_1650" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Spooning the mixture "][/caption] Spooning the mixture was easy---each blob held its shape and height. I decorated half the meringues in flaked almonds for extra crunch and and texture. [caption id="attachment_1651" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Decorated"][/caption] Patience is not my virtue; the notion of leaving this little drops of sugar in the oven for up to 6 hours was an anathema to me: I aimed for 3. The oven temperature needs to be extremely low, the idea is that you're drying out the blobs, not cooking them. I suspect an Aga would come in handy for regular meringue-making. [caption id="attachment_1653" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Just three hours later"][/caption] Just 3 hours later, I removed a dozen meringues from the oven. Chewy, sweet and crumbly---exactly what was I looking for. Just in time for a cup of tea and a break from packing. Recipe, inspired by Ottolenghi Makes about 10 large ones. 300g caster sugar (golden if you prefer a more caramelised flavour and colour) 5 eggs, whites only, at room temperature Lemon slice 1/4 cup of flaked almonds (optional) 1 tbsp of Amaretto (optional) 1. Heat the oven to 200C. Spread the sugar over an oven tray lined with baking parchment and cook until it has just begun to melt at the edges, but not caramelise (about 8 minutes). 2. Meanwhile, crack the eggs, being careful not to drop any yolk into your whites. If you lose any bits of shell, scoop them out with a clean spoon rather than your fingers. 3. Wipe the inside of your mixing bowl, and the whisk, with the cut side of the lemon and add the eggs. As soon as you spot the sugar beginning to melt at the edges, set the mixer to whisk at high speed while you take the sugar out of the oven. 4. The mixture should be just foamy by the time you add the sugar. Wearing oven gloves, pick up the baking parchment with oven gloves and tip the hot sugar slowly into the still-whisking mixer. Continue whisking until the mixture has cooled, and is glossy and will hold its shape. Turn the oven down to its lowest setting. 5. If you want to fold through any spices or other flavourings (a little Amaretto), or roll the meringues in nuts or another topping, this is your moment. 6. Line a baking tray with parchment, and spoon the meringue on in great gorgeous blobs – remember they'll increase in size as they dry out. Put them into the oven and bake until they are crisp on the outside, and sound hollow when tapped on the bottom: depending on their size, this could take six hours, so don't wait up. 7. Turn the oven off and leave them in there until it has cooled, then immediately transfer to an air-tight container.

item.title: A splash of Amaretto
item.dc:creator: nicki
item.content:encoded: It doesn't take much to put me in the mood for baking. A slight sugar craving, the distant creep of ennui, or some spare eggs knocking around the kitchen---all reason enough to whack the oven on, don an apron, and  beat some eggs. Things have been a little crazy around here lately. We're moving to London; the boy proposed over wood-roasted sea bream at Moro; I underwent five interviews in 48 hours, and now I'm taking a moment to breath---a little baking in the kitchen seemed like a good place to start. [caption id="attachment_1672" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="The basics"][/caption] I'am a loyal fan of almond-based biscuits. Having convinced myself almonds are better for the waist-line than flour, my taste buds tend to veer towards the macarons and meringues. I even make crumble with ground and flaked almonds---it's dense, but still delicious. So, I'd been reading about amaretti somewhere in the weekend papers, and since we had a bottle of Amaretto in the cupboard, the biscuits were begging to be made. [caption id="attachment_1673" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Adding almonds to whites"][/caption] Like all recipes involving stiff egg whites, the emphasis is on well-whipped and separated whites, glossy and aerated. After that it's a case of gently folding, making sure not to let the air out. If I'm honest, I've never really understood how you ensure no air is lost from the whites, but I guess if they're still looking fluffy you're doing ok. [caption id="attachment_1675" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Beating"][/caption] The sugar and almonds combine easily with the egg whites---I was using a fairly fast setting for the beating. Once you feel all the ingredients are incorporated you add the alcohol. [caption id="attachment_1676" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="A generous glug of Amaretto "][/caption] The mixture becomes more paste-like and very easy to work with. I did experiment with piping instead of spooning. The piped variants were a lot smaller and neater, but it's a personal preference, really. [caption id="attachment_1677" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="Baked and ready "][/caption] One or two recipes recommend a longer cooking period to dry out the biscuits. You can prop the oven door open with a wooden spoon, and leave the biscuits for another 20-30 minutes in the oven. This allows them to crisp up without colouring any further. [caption id="attachment_1678" align="aligncenter" width="589" caption="An amaretti pile, easily consumed "][/caption] These biscuits were too tasty---we ate them for breakfast, lunch and supper. They're light and delicious and easy to make. I highly recommend whipping up a batch. Recipe Ingredients 340g/12oz ground almonds 340g/12oz caster sugar 4 eggs, whites only 40ml/1fl oz amaretto liquor butter, for greasing flaked almonds for decorating (optional) Method Preheat the oven to 170C/325F/Gas 3. Separate your egg and in a large bowl beat the egg whites until firm. Mix the sugar and the almonds gently into it. Add the amaretto liquor and fold in gently until you have a smooth paste. Place some greaseproof paper on a baking sheet lightly brushed with butter. Using a teaspoon place small heaps of the mixture approximately 2cm apart, as they will expand whilst cooking. Decorate with a few flaked almonds. Bake in the oven for approximately 15 minutes until golden brown.
